(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-5-2. UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANKS; NOTIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Any person who supervises, manages or directs the installation,
retrofitting, removal or closure of underground storage tanks shall notify the
City of Lawrence Fire Department 14 days prior to commencement of work;
however, this requirement shall not apply in emergency repair work where 14-day
notification is not possible.
   (B)   All applicable permits and notification shall be made to the State
Fire Marshal’s Office and the Indiana Department of Environmental Management
prior to removing or closing underground storage tanks and all associated
piping.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-5-3. CONSUMER FIREWORKS; TIMES OF USE.
   (A)   Consumer fireworks, as defined by I.C. 22-11-14-1, may be used within
the corporate limits of the City of Lawrence only between the hours of 5:00
p.m. and two hours after sunset on June 29, June 30, July 1, July 2, July 3,
July 5, July 6, July 7, July 8, and July 9; between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and
12:00 midnight on July 4; and between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on December 31
and 1:00 a.m. on January 1. The use of consumer fireworks within the corporate
limits of the City of Lawrence is prohibited at all other times.
   (B)   Violation of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine
of up to $100 for a first offense and up to $250 for a second or subsequent
offense.
(Ord. 21, 2008, passed 9-2-2008)
§ 3-4-5-4. CONSUMER FIREWORKS; PLACES OF USE.
   (A)   Consumer fireworks, as defined by I.C. 22-11-14-1, may be used within
the corporate limits of the City of Lawrence only on the property of the user,
on the property of another who has given permission to use the consumer
fireworks or at a special discharge location as set forth in I.C. 22-11-14-3.5.
Consumer fireworks may not be used on or where, upon their use, they will or
are capable of reaching any public property or shared common areas, including
but not limited to municipal or other public parks, common or shared areas
pertaining to residence subdivisions or other residential areas and streets,
roads or any other public rights-of-way.
   (B)   This section may be enforced by any police or law enforcement officers
or personnel, including the Fire marshal and deputy fire marshal officers and
personnel. Violation of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a
fine of up to $100 for a first offense and up to $250 for a second or
subsequent offense.
(Ord. 12, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
CHAPTER 6. PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES OF INSURANCE
Section
   
3-4-6-1.   Fireworks
   
3-4-6-2.   Halloween amusement defined
   
3-4-6-3.   Required; permit application; permit and fees
   
3-4-6-4.   Retail firework stands or businesses
   
3-4-6-5.   Amusement inspections
   
3-4-6-6.   Permit issuance and transferability
   
3-4-6-7.   Appeal from denial of permit
   
3-4-6-8.   Permit period
   
3-4-6-9.   Display of permit required
§ 3-4-6-1. FIREWORKS.
   (A)   No person, group or business shall conduct a public display of
fireworks without first obtaining a permit from the City of Lawrence. Any and
all permits for the public display of fireworks shall be obtained by the
person, group or business that is conducting the display. The Board of Public
Works and Safety shall approve the permit.
   (B)   Fireworks and the temporary storage, use and handling of pyrotechnic
special effects material used in motion pictures, television, theatrical and
group entertainment productions shall be in accordance with I.C. 22-11-14 and
the applicable rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission
currently in effect.
   (C)   A certificate of insurance conditioned for the payment of all damages
which may be caused either to a person or persons in an amount of not less than
$1,000,000, holding the City of Lawrence harmless from liability shall be
reason for the licensed display, arising from any acts of the licensee, his or
her agents, employees or subcontractors. The certificate of insurance shall be
presented to the Clerk Treasurer for proper filing.
   (D)   The fee for each permit issued pursuant to each public display of
fireworks shall be $50 payable to the City of Lawrence.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
Cross-reference:
   Consumer fireworks, see §
3-4-5-3
§ 3-4-6-2. HALLOWEEN AMUSEMENT DEFINED.
   As used in this Article, HALLOWEEN AMUSEMENT means haunted house, house of
horrors or any other activity in which persons are invited, guided, escorted or
otherwise transported through a building or structure or portion of a building
or structure, temporary or permanent, for the purpose of entertainment or
amusement.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-6-3. REQUIRED; PERMIT APPLICATION; PERMIT AND FEES.
   (A)   No person shall operate a Halloween amusement without first obtaining
a permit from the City of Lawrence. The Board of Public Works and Safety shall
approve the permit.
   (B)   An application for a Halloween amusement permit shall be obtained from
the City of Lawrence and shall contain the following information.
      (1)   The name of the organization sponsoring the amusement;
      (2)   The name of the person(s) in charge of the amusement operations;
      (3)   The period of time (dates and hours) in which the amusement will be
operated; and
      (4)   The person or organization wishing to obtain a permit to operate a
Halloween amusement shall provide a certificate of insurance in an amount not
less than $1,000,000 holding the City of Lawrence harmless from any liability.
   (C)   The fee for each permit issued pursuant to this code shall be $250
payable to the City of Lawrence. The certificate of insurance shall be
presented to the City Controller for proper filing.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-6-4. RETAIL FIREWORK STANDS OR BUSINESSES.
   An individual or company who desires to sell wholesale or retail fireworks
within the City of Lawrence shall obtain a permit from the State of Indiana
prior to the selling of merchandise to the general public.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-6-5. AMUSEMENT INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The authorized representative of the Fire Prevention Bureau shall
inspect the building or structure and the Halloween amusement as often as may
be reasonably necessary for compliance with applicable fire and life safety
requirements for their intended occupancies.
   (B)   Such inspections shall occur after the issuance of a permit, during
facility construction and during the permit period.
   (C)   Permits issued for Halloween amusements shall expire 30 days after
issuance of the permit.
   (D)   Violations found during any inspection conducted by the City of
Lawrence Fire Department’s Fire Prevention Bureau shall cause the amusement to
shut down in accordance with I.C.36-8-17-9 and the revocation of the permit.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-6-6. PERMIT ISSUANCE AND TRANSFERABILITY.
   (A)   A Halloween amusement permit shall be issued only after the City of
Lawrence Fire Department’s Fire Prevention Bureau has had an opportunity to
inspect the subject premises, and has found that the building or structure and
amusement conforms with all applicable fire and life safety requirements as set
forth in the applicable rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety
Commission currently in effect and this code.
   (B)   A permit issued pursuant to this code shall not be transferable, and
any change in use or occupancy of premises shall require a new permit.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-6-7. APPEAL FROM DENIAL OF PERMIT.
   When the City of Lawrence Fire Department rejects or refuses to grant a
permit required by this code, or when it is claimed that provisions of this
section of this code relating thereto do not apply, the person may appeal the
decision in writing to the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-6-8. PERMIT PERIOD.
   Each permit granted under the provisions of this code shall be for the
period indicated on the permit and permit application; however, such permit
shall expire 30 days from the date it is issued.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-6-9. DISPLAY OF PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A permit issued pursuant to this code shall at all times be in a conspicuous
place on the premises designated in the permit and shall at all times be
subject to inspection by anyone duly authorized by the Fire or Police
Department.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
CHAPTER 7. OUTSIDE FIRE PROTECTION
Section
   
3-4-7-1.   Fire protection by the City of Lawrence Fire Department outside the
City of Lawrence
§ 3-4-7-1. FIRE PROTECTION BY THE CITY OF LAWRENCE FIRE DEPARTMENT OUTSIDE THE
CITY OF LAWRENCE.
   The City of Lawrence Fire Department may provide fire protection or services
outside the boundaries of the City of Lawrence, only under the following
circumstances and upon the following conditions:
   (A)   If the Board of Public Works and Safety enters into any mutual aid
agreement with any existing municipal fire department or with the chief
executive officer of any unit of government which maintains or finances an
established fire department, wherein the agreement provides for the mutual
assistance between the City of Lawrence Fire Department and the other fire
departments such that the ranking officer of the respective department may
request, when necessary, the assistance without charge to the assisted
department. The City of Lawrence Fire Department is authorized to render such
assistance as is requested by the ranking officer on duty with the respective
department so long as the rendering of that assistance shall not endanger the
citizens of the City of Lawrence or threaten the ability of the City of
Lawrence Fire Department to render services within the City of Lawrence.
   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety, upon approval of the Mayor, may
enter into a contract with any person, business, municipality or other
governmental unit which is situated at a place not within the City of Lawrence,
but within the county and which is desirous of contracting with the City of
Lawrence for regular fire protection involving the use and services of the City
of Lawrence Fire Department. The details of the contract shall be specified by
the Board of Public Works and Safety, but each contract must provide that the
City furnish on a calendar year basis such firefighting service and emergency
services as may be reasonably necessary on the request of the contracting
person, municipality or other governmental unit, but that obligation to render
those services shall not exist at any time that the same would endanger or
threaten the services of the City of Lawrence Fire Department to the citizens
of the City of Lawrence. The contract shall also provide for a negotiated rate
or fees payable as required by the Board of Public Works and Safety for the
rendering of such services and may provide for additional charges based on the
actual services and apparatus used in the performance of the agreement.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
CHAPTER 8. FIRE REPORTING SYSTEMS
Section
   
3-4-8-1.   Scope of division
   
3-4-8-2.   Monitoring of fire systems
   
3-4-8-3.   Notification upon fire alarm activation and emergency reporting
   
3-4-8-4.   False alarms
§ 3-4-8-1. SCOPE OF DIVISION.
   This code shall cover installation and maintenance of all manual and
automatic fire alarm systems in new and existing buildings; also, faulty and/or
false alarms and delayed notification of manual or automatic systems.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-8-2. MONITORING OF FIRE SYSTEMS.
   Fire alarm systems required by the applicable rules of the Fire Prevention
and Building Safety Commission or this code shall be monitored as set forth in
the applicable rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission and
the current edition of N.F.P.A. Standard No. 72 or the most current edition of
the standard by an approved central proprietary or remote station service or a
local alarm which gives audible and visual signals as a constantly attended
location.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-8-3. NOTIFICATION UPON FIRE ALARM ACTIVATION AND EMERGENCY REPORTING.
   The City of Lawrence Fire Department shall be notified upon the activation
of any fire alarm.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-8-4. FALSE ALARMS.
   (A)   Whenever the City of Lawrence Fire Department responds to any fire
alarm, medical alarm or emergency telephone call at a residence, business,
premises or building more than three times in a annual calendar period due to
improper alarm installation, lack of maintenance, servicing, employee and/or
occupant failure or false reporting, a service charge shall be imposed.
   (B)   For a fourth response, the service charge will be $50. For a fifth
response, the service charge shall be $75. For sixth and subsequent responses
the service charge shall be $100 per each response.
   (C)   Such service charges shall be made payable to the City of Lawrence.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
CHAPTER 9. OPEN BURNING
Section
   
3-4-9-1.   Open burning
   
3-4-9-2.   Open burning for special purposes
§ 3-4-9-1. OPEN BURNING.
   (A)   No person shall kindle or maintain any bonfire or burn leaves, rubbish
or dispose of any refuse by open burning, or shall knowingly furnish the
materials for any such fire, or authorize any such fire to be kindled or
maintained on or in any street, alley, roads, land or public grounds.
   (B)   No person shall kindle or maintain any burning leaves or rubbish on
any private land or dispose of any refuse by open burning, or cause, suffer,
allow or permit open burning on any private land.
   (C)    Open burning shall be only be permitted as specified in §
3-4-9-2 of this code.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
§ 3-4-9-2. OPEN BURNING FOR SPECIAL PURPOSES.
   Permitted open burning is as follows:
   (A)   A bonfire in connection with a religious ceremony, school pep rally,
scouting activities and similar purposes;
   (B)   Campfire and fires for cookouts;
   (C)   Fires required for personal comfort or a bonfire in connection with
recreational activities, including but not limited to sledding and ice-skating;
   (D)   Open burning of plant life grown on the premises in the course of
agricultural operations. It can be shown that such open burning is necessary
and that no fire hazard will occur, provided the person intending to dispose of
plant life by open burning shall obtain approval from the fire department which
has jurisdiction and from the Indianapolis Air Pollution Control Division. Any
open burning permitted under the provision of this section shall be allowed
only between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. and only at times when the
actual or forecast wind speed as given by the local National Weather Service is
greater than five miles per hour and less than 20 miles per hour. Such fires
shall consist of plant life only;
   (E)   Fires shall be permitted in wood stoves for heating and fireplaces if
the fire does not create an air pollution problem or fire hazard; and
   (F)   Residents of single or double family dwellings located on one or more
residential lots shall be allowed to burn only dried limbs, twigs and branches
(but not leaves) originating on their or contiguous premises, but only between
the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. Burning shall be more than 15 feet from
any structure in a noncombustible container, sufficiently vented to induce
adequate primary combustion air, with enclosed sides, a bottom and a mesh
covering with openings not greater than one-fourth inch. If the fire creates a
health hazard, it shall be extinguished.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
CHAPTER 10. CONCLUSION
Section
   
3-4-10-1.   Conclusion
§ 3-4-10-1. CONCLUSION.
   (A)   The expressed or implied repeal or amendment by this code of any other
code or part of any other code does not affect any rights or liabilities
accrued, penalties incurred or proceedings begun prior to the effective date of
this code. Those rights, liabilities and proceedings are continued, and
penalties shall be imposed and enforced under the repealed or amended ordinance
as if this code had not been adopted.
   (B)   Should any provision (section, division, paragraph, sentence, clause
or any other portion) of this code be declared by a court of competent
jurisdiction to be invalid for any reason, the remaining provision or
provisions shall not be affected, if and only if such remaining provisions can,
without the invalid provision or provisions, be given the effect intended by
the Common Council in adopting this code. To this end the provisions of this
code are severable.
   (C)   Penalties hereby imposed and identified pursuant to this
Article 4, Chapters
1 through
10, as set out under the Indiana Code for violations found are hereby adopted
and approved.
(Ord. 5, 2005, passed 6-6-2005)
ARTICLE 5. PLANNING AND ZONING
CHAPTER 1. PLAN COMMISSION
Section
   
3-5-1-1.   Lawrence Plan Commission established
   
3-5-1-2.   Membership
   
3-5-1-3.   Terms
   
3-5-1-4.   Duties
   
3-5-1-5.   Effect of this chapter
   
3-5-1-6.   Cooperation with Marion County
   
3-5-1-7.   Creation of a new Lawrence comprehensive plan and zoning ordinance
§ 3-5-1-1. LAWRENCE PLAN COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   Pursuant to I.C. 36-7-4-202 and other applicable law, there is hereby
established an advisory plan commission for the City of Lawrence to be known as
the "Lawrence Plan Commission" with all authority under I.C. 36-7-4 and all
amendments thereto.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
§ 3-5-1-2. MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   The membership of the Lawrence Plan Commission shall be as provided by
I.C. 36-7-4-207(a) as follows:
      (1)   One member appointed by the City Council from its membership.
      (2)   One member appointed by the Park Board.
      (3)   One member or designated representative appointed by the City
Public Works Board.
      (4)   The City Civil Engineer or a qualified assistant appointed by the
City Civil Engineer.
      (5)   Five citizen members, of whom no more than three may be of the same
political party, appointed by the Mayor.
      (B)   The City Clerk and the Secretary of the Park Board shall certify
members appointed by their respective bodies, and the Mayor shall certify the
Mayor's appointments. The certificates shall be sent to and made a part of the
records of the municipal Plan Commission.
      (C)   Citizen members shall be duly qualified. Each citizen member shall
be appointed because of the member's knowledge and experience in community
affairs, the member's awareness of the social, economic, agricultural, and
industrial problems of the area, and the member's interest in the development
and integration of the area. A citizen member may not hold an elected office
(as defined in I.C. 3-5-2.1-34); or any other appointed office in municipal,
county, or state government, except in the case of an area Plan Commission,
membership on the body from which the member must be appointed under state law.
Members must be residents of the City of Lawrence.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
§ 3-5-1-3. TERMS.
   Terms of appointed official members shall coincide with their term of office
or employment, except that the City Council at the first regular meeting of any
year may appoint another to serve as its representative. Initial terms of the
five citizen members shall be one for a term of two years, two for a term of
three years, and two for a term of four years. Initial terms of citizen members
shall expire on the first day of January of the second, third and fourth year,
respectively, following their initial appointments. Thereafter, as terms
expire, each new appointment shall be for a term of four years.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
§ 3-5-1-4. DUTIES.
   The responsibilities, duties, powers, and procedures of the Lawrence Plan
Commission shall be as set forth in I.C. 36-7-4 as amended and all other
applicable laws and City ordinances. The Lawrence Plan Commission shall meet
within 30 days of its establishment to elect officers, adopt procedures,
determine rules of operation, adopt an official seal, determine application
procedures and establish a calendar of regular meetings. The administration
shall prepare a budget and staffing for the Plan Commission for each fiscal
year.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
§ 3-5-1-5. EFFECT OF THIS CHAPTER.
   It is the intent of Lawrence that this chapter and the acts hereunder not
abrogate or alter the prior and currently applicable planning and zoning
ordinance, rules, and regulations applicable within the City as part of Marion
County, subject only to the transfer of functions attendant to Lawrence's
jurisdiction effective July 1, 2021 under I.C. 36-7-4-201(d) and the
establishment of the Lawrence Plan Commission under the advisory planning law.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
§ 3-5-1-6. COOPERATION WITH MARION COUNTY.
   The Lawrence planning staff, Lawrence Plan Commission, Lawrence Board of
Zoning Appeals, and all other applicable Lawrence officials, agencies, boards
and commissions, shall cooperate with the Marion County Metropolitan Planning
Department, Marion County, and all other applicable Marion County officials,
agencies, boards, and commissions as may be necessary and appropriate in
furtherance of Lawrence's jurisdiction under I.C. 36-7-4-201(d) and
establishment of the Lawrence Plan Commission under the advisory planning law,
and to provide for the continuous coverage of planning and zoning functions in
and around Lawrence, and in a manner to ensure that no gaps exist in the
planning and zoning functions in and around Lawrence.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
§ 3-5-1-7. CREATION OF A NEW LAWRENCE COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE.
   (A)   The Lawrence planning staff, Lawrence Plan Commission, and Lawrence
Board of Zoning Appeals are hereafter directed to undertake a review of all
applicable planning and zoning ordinances, applications, forms, permits, fees,
rules, procedures, or other similar planning and zoning documents and
materials, and to take all necessary and appropriate action to provide for
adequate and proper planning and zoning for the City, including but not limited
to making such publications, amendments, revisions, or recommendations as may
be necessary or appropriate in furtherance of their functions or Lawrence's
operation under the advisory planning law. No later than September 1, 2022, the
Plan Commission shall prepare, conduct public hearings, and recommend to the
Common Council the following:
      (1)   A comprehensive plan for the physical development of the City and
other tools useful for implementing the comprehensive plan;
      (2)   A zoning ordinance and zoning map;
      (3)   A subdivision control ordinance;
      (4)   A historic preservation plan as needed for any historic district;
      (5)   A capital improvement program; and
      (6)   A program for citizen education in planning and good public
relations in the community.
   (B)   The Plan Commission shall also:
      (1)   Review all petitions for amendments to the zoning ordinance and map
and recommend their approval or disapproval to the Common Council;
      (2)   Review and approve or disapprove subdivision plats;
      (3)   Perform special studies as requested by the Common Council;
      (4)   Hold public hearings, as necessary, to receive comments from the
public concerning the creation of, and any changes to, the comprehensive plan,
zoning ordinance, and other land use control regulations;
      (5)   Review and revise the comprehensive plan, zoning ordinance,
subdivision regulations, and capital improvement programs to keep them up to
date and adjusted to changing conditions; and
      (6)   Provide day-to-day advice and guidance to individuals regarding
physical development, zoning, and code regulations.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
CHAPTER 2. TEMPORARY ADOPTION OF THE CITY OF INDIANAPOLIS ZONING CODE
Section
   
3-5-2-1.   Reaffirmation of Comprehensive Plan and Zoning Ordinance Applicable
to Marion County
§ 3-5-2-1. REAFFIRMATION OF COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE APPLICABLE
TO MARION COUNTY.
   Zoning matters before the Lawrence Board of Zoning Appeals and the Common
Council shall be governed by the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Indianapolis,
codified in the Revised Code of the Consolidated City of Indianapolis (Ord. No.
64, 2015, § 1(Exhibit), passed September 28, 2015, effective April 1, 2016) and
hereby reaffirmed as adopted from at Title III as follows:
   (A)   Zoning ordinance, zoning districts, use and use specific standards,
and development standards. Chapter 740, Articles I through VI, Sections 101
through 603, Articles VII through IX, Sections 801 through 1008, and Chapters
742, 743 and 744. The Lawrence planning staff shall interpret and enforce such
provisions, and the Lawrence Plan Commission and Lawrence Board of Zoning
Appeals shall apply and enforce such provisions for the City, consistent with
Lawrence's jurisdiction under I.C. 36-7-4-201(d) and establishment of the
Lawrence Plan Commission under the advisory planning law.
   (B)   Zoning maps. Article 1, Chapter 740, Section 103. The zoning maps, as
the same may have been amended from time to time and which prior to this date
applied to the areas within Lawrence's jurisdiction, are hereby reaffirmed as
adopted for Lawrence. The Lawrence planning staff shall interpret and enforce
such provisions of the Lawrence Zoning Maps, and the Lawrence Plan Commission
and Lawrence Board of Zoning Appeals shall apply and enforce such maps for the
City, consistent with Lawrence's jurisdiction under I.C. 36-7-4-201(d) and
establishment of the Lawrence Plan Commission under the advisory planning law.
   (C)   Subdivision Control Ordinance. Chapter 741. The Subdivision Control
Ordinance, as the same may have been amended from time to time, and which prior
to this date applied to the areas within Lawrence's jurisdiction, is hereby
reaffirmed as adopted for Lawrence. The Lawrence planning staff shall interpret
and enforce such provisions of the Lawrence Subdivision Control Ordinance, and
the Lawrence Plan Commission and Lawrence Board of Zoning Appeals shall apply
and enforce such provisions for the City consistent with Lawrence's
jurisdiction under I.C. 36-7-4-201(d) and establishment of the Lawrence Plan
Commission under the advisory planning law.
   (D)   Planning and zoning documents and materials. Until such time as the
Lawrence planning staff, Lawrence Plan Commission, or Lawrence Board of Zoning
Appeals, as the case may be, adopts new applications, forms, permits, fees,
rules, procedures, or other similar planning and zoning documents and materials
necessary or appropriate for the exercise of planning and zoning functions, the
materials utilized for the same functions before the Metropolitan Plan
Commission previously hereto applicable to Lawrence's participation therein
shall be in effect and may be utilized by the applicable Lawrence agency, body,
commission, or other interested person or party.
   (E)   Interpretation consistent with establishment of advisory planning. The
use of the terms "County," "Marion County," "Area Plan Commission," "Board of
Zoning Appeals," "Director," and other similar terms referencing Marion County
or the Indianapolis-Marion County Department of Metropolitan Development in any
applicable ordinance, regulation, or planning and zoning document or material,
including but not limited to the ordinances and materials specifically
referenced in this chapter, shall instead be interpreted to reference or refer
to "Lawrence," "Lawrence Plan Commission," "Lawrence Board of Zoning Appeals,"
"Lawrence Planning Director," or other similar Lawrence office, agency, board,
commission, or authority, where necessary or appropriate in furtherance of
Lawrence's jurisdiction under I.C. 36-7-4-201(d) and establishment of the
Lawrence Plan Commission under the advisory planning law.
(Ord. 11, 2021, passed 9-7-2021)
TITLE 4. BUSINESS AND COMMERCE
         
ARTICLE 1.   GENERAL BUSINESS PROVISIONS
         
ARTICLE 2.   SPECIFIC BUSINESS REGULATIONS
ARTICLE 1. GENERAL BUSINESS PROVISIONS
CHAPTER 1. PERMITS; GENERALLY
Section
   
4-1-1-1.   General permit requirements
   
4-1-1-2.   Applications for permits
   
4-1-1-3.   Qualifications of applicants
   
4-1-1-4.   Duties of licensee
   
4-1-1-5.   Revocation of license; forfeiture of fee
   
4-1-1-6.   Fees; duration
§ 4-1-1-1. GENERAL PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   Whenever in this code it is required that any person, firm or corporation
obtain a license or permit from the Department of Public Works prior to
engaging in any type of activity or business enterprise that is regulated or
licensed by the City of Lawrence, the person, firm or corporation shall comply
with the provisions of this chapter as well as the provisions of any other
chapter of this code applicable to the activity or business enterprise.
Penalty, see § 1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-1-2. APPLICATIONS FOR PERMITS.
   (A)   All applications for licenses or permits required by this code shall
be submitted on forms provided by the Department of Public Works, and the
applicant shall provide all information requested thereon.
   (B)   All applications shall be filed with the Department of Public Works,
which shall examine the applications for completeness and compliance with the
requirements of this code and shall issue permits to all applicants who
qualify.
   (C)   Failure to completely and accurately provide the information required
in any permit application, or the giving of false or misleading information,
intentional or otherwise, shall be grounds for denial or revocation of a
permit.
   (D)   Failure of any applicant to comply with any of the qualifications of
applicants or duties of licensees prescribed in this code shall likewise be
grounds for denial or revocation of a permit.
§ 4-1-1-3. QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANTS.
   (A)   The general standards herein set out relative to the qualifications of
every applicant for a City license shall be considered and applied by the
Department of Public Works.
   (B)   The applicant shall:
      (1)   Be of good moral character. In making that determination, the
Department of Public Works shall consider:
         (a)   All convictions, the reasons therefor and the conduct of the
applicant subsequent thereto;
         (b)    The license history of the applicant, whether the person, in
previously operating under a license in this or another state, has had the
license revoked or suspended, the reasons therefor and the conduct of the
applicant subsequent to the action;
         (c)   A routine check with the Better Business Bureau will be made of
all applicants to determine whether there is a history of consumer complaints
lodged against the applicants as a result of prior business dealings with the
public; and
         (d)   Other facts relevant to the general personal history of the
applicant as are necessary to a fair determination of the eligibility for a
City license.
      (2)   Not be in default under the provisions of any chapter of this code
or indebted or obligated in any manner to the City except for current taxes.
§ 4-1-1-4. DUTIES OF LICENSEE.
   Every entity holding a license or permit pursuant to any chapter of this
code shall:
   (A)   Permit all reasonable inspections of its business and merchandise and
examination of his or her books by police personnel or other public authorities
so authorized by law or the Common Council;
   (B)   Ascertain and at all times comply with all laws, ordinances and
regulations, including this chapter, applicable to the licensed business;
   (C)   Post the license issued under this chapter in a conspicuous place
within any licensed premises; and
   (D)   Cease business. Refrain from transacting any type of licensed business
activities after the expiration of the license.
Penalty, see § 1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-1-5. REVOCATION OF LICENSE; FORFEITURE OF FEE.
   (A)   In the event that complaints are received relating to the conduct of
any entity transacting business pursuant to any license issued by the City of
Lawrence, the Mayor, upon reasonable notice to the licensee, shall hold a
hearing as prescribed by I.C. 36-4-5-5.
   (B)   The Mayor shall have the authority to revoke any permit or license
issued under this code to any entity upon the showing of a conviction of that
person, firm, corporation or principal or part owner of any business holding
the permit or license for violation of any criminal statute of any state or the
United States.
   (C)   Likewise, if the Mayor finds that the license holder has willfully
violated a term or condition of a license, or has willfully done or permitted
to be done an act in violation of a statute or City ordinance relating to the
business licensed, the Mayor shall revoke or suspend the license.
   (D)   Any license revoked by the Mayor shall cause a forfeiture of all
license fees paid by the licensee for any and all licenses so revoked.
§ 4-1-1-6. FEES; DURATION.
   (A)   For each permit issued under any chapter of this code, there shall be
paid to the Department of Public Works the fee prescribed by that chapter.
   (B)   For any permit issued after July 1 of any year, the permit fee shall
be one-half of the fee prescribed by the relevant chapter.
   (C)   Unless otherwise specified in a particular chapter, all permits are
valid only for the calendar year in which they are issued and expire on
December 31 of the year of issuance.
CHAPTER 2. PEDDLERS
Section
   
4-1-2-1.   Definition; permit required
   
4-1-2-2.   Fees; duration
   4-1-2-2.5.   Peddlers and solicitors entering upon private premises
   
4-1-2-3.   Exemptions
   
4-1-2-4.   Qualifications of applicants
   
4-1-2-5.   Duties of licensee
§ 4-1-2-1. DEFINITION; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CANVASSER. A person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at
his or her residence without prior specific invitation or appointment from the
resident for the noncommercial primary purpose of:
      (1)   Attempting to solicit support for or against a particular religion,
philosophy, ideology, political party, issue, or candidate, even if incidental
to such purposes the canvasser accepts the donation of money for or against
such cause; or,
      (2)   Attempting to obtain a donation to a particular patriotic,
philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic,
fraternal, charitable, political, or religious purpose, even if incidental to
such purpose there is the sale of some good or service.
   PEDDLER. A person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at
his or her residence without specific prior invitation or appointment from the
resident with the primary purpose of selling, attempting to sell, solicit, or
attempting to solicit, a good or service, regardless of whether the good or
service is provided at the time of contact. All peddlers must first obtain a
permit as herein provided before engaging in said business. No person shall be
engaged as a PEDDLER without first complying with the requirements herein.
Failure to obtain a permit or violation of any provision of this chapter shall
be punishable as prescribed in §
1-1-2-3.
(Am. Ord. 4, 2011, passed 5-2-2011; Am. Ord. 10, 2015, passed 8-3-2015)
§ 4-1-2-2. FEES; DURATION.
   (A)   For each permit issued to each person to sell or offer for sale goods
of any type to be offered in any manner prescribed by §
4-1-2-1, there shall be paid to the City Controller the sum of $50 for the
permit issued.
   (B)   Each permit shall be valid for 12 months from the date of issue.
   (C)   Holders of permits granted by the Indiana Utility Regulatory
Commission, as defined in I.C. § 8-1-34-6, shall be considered to have met the
requirements of this section for obtaining a permit and no further payments or
permits shall be required. These holders are still required to comply with §
4-1-2-5 herein.
   (D)   Those peddlers working on behalf of a not-for-profit corporation may
provide evidence of non-profit status to the Controller and have the
aforementioned fee waived.
   (E)   Canvassers are not required to obtain a permit, but are encouraged to
do so to reassure city residents of their good faith.
   (F)   Permits are non-transferable and may only be used by the original
individual applicant.
(Am. Ord. 4, 2011, passed 5-2-2011; Am. Ord. 10, 2015, passed 8-3-2015)
§ 4-1-2-2.5. PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS ENTERING UPON PRIVATE PREMISES.
   The practice of entering upon the premises of private residences in the City
by any person or persons acting as solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant
merchants or transient vendors of merchandise of any kind, magazines,
pamphlets, books or any other articles or the provision of services or cost
estimates for services when such person has not been requested or invited to do
so by the owner or occupant of the private residence, of when a notice is
posted at or near the entrance thereof forbidding such entry for any such
purposes, with the intention of selling or soliciting orders for the sale of
any such things or services, or of peddling, hawking or otherwise disposing
thereof, or doing all of any of such practices is hereby prohibited and shall
be punishable as prescribed in §
1-1-2-3.
(Ord. 4, 2011, passed 5-2-2011) Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-2-3. EXEMPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the sale of items by
nonprofit, recognized organizations consisting solely of and serving only youth
under 18 years of age, such as Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts and Boys and Girls
Clubs, and the sale of newspapers, nor to any person or firms maintaining
factories, warehouses, dairies or bakeries and delivering milk or bread or
other wares or merchandise over regularly established routes or selling at
wholesale to local merchants or mercantile establishments and shall not apply
to any produce of the soil, dairy product or fruit raised or produced by the
person peddling or offering the same for sale.
(Am. Ord. 4, 2011, passed 5-2-2011)
§ 4-1-2-4. QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANTS.
   In addition to the qualifications prescribed by §
4-1-1-3, applicants for licenses under this chapter shall:
   (A)   Fixed location sales. Furnish a written authorization from the owner
of the property for the use of the area for selling;
   (B)   Food sales. Obtain liability insurance in the sum of at least
$1,000,000 and shall provide the City of Lawrence with a copy of the
certificate of insurance. All food sales must have a valid permit from the
Indiana State Board of Health and must display the permit in a prominent
location within the selling area or vehicle; and
   (C)   Vehicular sales. Be safety inspected by the Lawrence Police Department
and must comply with all state and local requirements for the vehicles.
Penalty, see § 1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-2-5. DUTIES OF LICENSEE.
   In addition to the duties prescribed by §
4-1-1-4, every licensee under this chapter shall:
   (A)   Operate properly. Avoid rude, insolent, hostile and argumentative
conduct or any conduct, practice or condition which negatively affects the
public health, morals or welfare. Where any individual has declined the good or
service offered by the licensee or expressly requested that licensee should
leave the property, licensee shall refrain from approaching the person again in
any manner or from any further offering of the goods or services for sale to
the person or household; and
   (B)   Display of license. Every licensee under this chapter shall keep the
license issued:
      (1)   Taped in the front window on the driver's side of the vehicle, for
sales from vehicles; and
      (2)   Posted in a conspicuous place within the licensed premises, for
fixed location sales; and
      (3)   Visibly displayed on the person, for door to door peddler
activities.
   (C)   Operate only during daylight hours. For the safety of all persons,
door to door activities, including but not limited to peddlers and canvassers,
may only be conducted during daylight hours.
(Am. Ord. 4, 2011, passed 5-2-2011; Am. Ord. 10, 2015, passed 8-3-2015)
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
CHAPTER 3. PAWNSHOPS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS
Section
   
4-1-3-1.   Definitions
   
4-1-3-2.   Permit required; garage sale exception
   
4-1-3-3.   Fees
   
4-1-3-4.   Record of purchases required
   
4-1-3-5.   Records and property open to inspection by police
   
4-1-3-6.   Prohibited purchases
   
4-1-3-7.   Retention of acquired property
   
4-1-3-8.   Dealers in junk prohibited
   
4-1-3-9.   Suspension or revocation of permit
   
4-1-3-10.   Penalty
§ 4-1-3-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   GARAGE SALE. Selling or offering for sale any used, tangible, personal
property at any residence or other location which is zoned under the Dwelling
Districts Zoning Ordinance of Marion County.
   (B)   PAWNBROKER.
      (1)   Any person who, as a part of his or her regular business, loans
money on the deposit or pledge of any personal property or thing of value on
the condition of redelivering or selling the article back again at a stipulated
price.
      (2)   Any person who shall pay cash advances on the consignment of
merchandise to be sold.
      (3)   Any person who, as a part of his or her regular business practice,
dispenses and receives pawn tickets to and from individuals so that the
individuals may redeem merchandise.
      (4)   Any person who shall, as a part of his or her regular business,
renegotiate pawn loans between individuals and other pawnbrokers.
   (C)   PAWNSHOP. Any place of business utilized or maintained for carrying on
the transactions of a pawnbroker.
   (D)   SECONDHAND DEALER. Any person who keeps a place of business for the
purchase or sale of used clothing, furniture, goods or merchandise of any kind.
§ 4-1-3-2. PERMIT REQUIRED; GARAGE SALE EXCEPTION.
   (A)   Every person, firm or corporation who shall sell, offer for sale,
purchase or offer to purchase any type of used goods or who shall operate or
maintain a pawnshop within the City shall, before engaging in the business,
obtain a permit therefor from the City Controller as provided herein.
   (B)   Each permit issued pursuant to this section shall be valid for a
period of one year from the date of issuance unless earlier suspended or
revoked.
   (C)   Excepted from the requirements of this chapter are garage sales,
provided that the frequency of the sales do not exceed an aggregate of ten days
at any one location within any calendar year.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to hold or allow to be held any
garage sale at any location for any aggregate period in excess of ten days in
any calendar year without first obtaining the proper commercial zoning
classification and otherwise complying with the requirements of this code and
other applicable law.
Penalty, see § 4-1-3-10
§ 4-1-3-3. FEES.
   (A)   For each permit issued or renewed under this chapter, there shall be
paid to the City Controller the sum of $100.
   (B)   Permits are valid only for a single business location as listed on the
application form.
§ 4-1-3-4. RECORD OF PURCHASES REQUIRED.
   (A)   Every person licensed under this section shall keep and preserve a
record, in written or electronic form as directed and approved by the license
administrator, of all personal property purchased by the licensee or accepted
by the licensee as a pledge.
   (B)   When receiving the personal property, the licensee shall
simultaneously enter the following information into the records required by the
section:
      (1)   An accurate account and description of each and every article
purchased or accepted;
      (2)   The name, age, color or ethnicity, height, weight, complexion,
style of beard or mustache, any distinguishing physical characteristics, style
of dress, address, telephone number, and number of any license badge of the
person selling or delivering the article;
      (3)   In the case of any purchase from a person under the age of 18
years, the name, age and address of the person's parent or guardian;
      (4)   The price paid therefor and the amount of money loaned on each
article pawned or the purchase price of each article purchased;
      (5)   The exact date and hour of the transaction;
      (6)   A copy of an identification card issued to the seller by the United
State government or by the government of the state or territory of the United
States or the District of Columbia;
      (7)   A photograph of the seller;
      (8)   The number of the pawn ticket issued; and
      (9)   Any other information as required by the license administrator.
      (10)   No entry in the book shall be erased, obliterated, revised with
correction fluid, defaced or otherwise changed.
   (C)   In addition to the record book required by this chapter, all
permittees under this chapter shall fill out one of the cards prescribed by
this section for each article pawned, sold, or otherwise received. The
permittee shall complete the card in its entirety. The customer shall write in
his or her own handwriting his or her name and address on the card; if the
person is unable to write, the person shall sign his or her mark and the
pawnbroker shall record on the card such information as will enable the
permittee to identify the person in case of the loss the ticket. The customer
shall place his or her right thumbprint on the back of the card. If the right
thumb is missing, any of the customer's fingerprints may be used. A clear print
must be obtained and both the signature and thumbprint must be retained by the
permittee in written or electronic form, as directed and approved by the
license administrator, for a minimum period of three years.
   (D)   The card record required by division (C) above shall be a form
prescribed by the Chief of Police which shall contain at least the following
information: the printed name and the signature of the customer, the full
address of the customer and the date of birth, sex, height, weight, color of
hair, color of eyes, skin color or race and the identification number of a
valid driver's license or photo identification of the customer. In addition,
the card shall state with respect to each article pawned or otherwise received
the following specific information to the fullest extent possible: the name of
the secondhand dealer or pawnbroker; the name and complete description of the
article, including its manufacturer, make, model, color, size and serial
number; the date and time of the transaction; whether the article was
consigned, traded, purchased, sold or pawned; the pawn ticket number and the
amount paid or loaned for the article. Except as provided in division (B)
above, the card shall be typed and shall be fully legible. A separate card
shall be prepared for each item of merchandise sold or pawned except for audio
compact disks, audio tapes, phonograph records and video game cartridges, in
which instances multiple numbers of each item may be recorded on the same card.
(Am. Ord. 28, 2012, passed 12-19-2012; Am. Ord. 17, 2015, passed 8-19-2015)
Penalty, see §
4-1-3-10
§ 4-1-3-5. RECORDS AND PROPERTY OPEN TO INSPECTION BY POLICE.
   The book required to be kept by this chapter, as well as every article of
secondhand merchandise purchased or received, shall at all reasonable times be
open to inspection by any member of the Police Department.
Penalty, see § 4-1-3-10
§ 4-1-3-6. PROHIBITED PURCHASES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any permittee under this chapter to purchase
or receive any articles in the course of his or her business from any person
who is intoxicated or who is known or suspected by the permittee to have
acquired or to be disposing of the articles unlawfully.
   (B)   No secondhand dealer or pawnbroker shall purchase or receive any
property whatsoever from any person under the age of 18 years without having
first obtained the written consent of the parent or guardian of the minor to
the sale.
   (C)   No secondhand dealer or pawnbroker shall purchase or accept as
collateral security any property of the type given manufacturers’ serial
numbers or other identifying insignia, unless the property shall have plainly
visible thereon the manufacturer’s serial number or other identifying insignia.
Penalty, see § 4-1-3-10
§ 4-1-3-7. RETENTION OF ACQUIRED PROPERTY.
   (A)   All property received by a permittee under this chapter shall be held
intact by the permittee for at least seven days.
   (B)   Whenever any permittee receives written notice, either from the Police
Department or from an individual, that someone is maintaining claim of right to
possession of the property adverse to the permittee, the permittee shall keep
the property in his or her possession or turn it over to the police if so
required by the Chief of Police.
Penalty, see § 4-1-3-10
§ 4-1-3-8. DEALERS IN JUNK PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to maintain a place
of business within the corporate limits of the City for the purpose of the
purchase or sale of junk or any type of scrap material, including, but not
limited to, scrap metals, wrecked vehicles or used vehicle parts, old rags,
canvas, paper or other similar materials, provided that this section shall not
be construed so as to prohibit the placement of enclosed, sturdy containers on
public or private property for the purpose of collecting newspaper, aluminum
cans, glass bottles and other similar materials suitable for recycling and
pending transport to a recycling facility.
Penalty, see § 4-1-3-10
§ 4-1-3-9. SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   The Board of Public Works and Safety may suspend the permit issued under
this chapter to any person, partnership or corporation for a period of up to
one year or may revoke the permit of any person, partnership or corporation if
one of the following is shown:
   (A)   The permittee made any materially false statement of fact on his, her
or its application for a permit or on the records or reports required to be
maintained and furnished by this chapter;
   (B)   The permittee has repeatedly failed or refused to timely abide by the
reporting requirements of this chapter;
   (C)   Repeated violation of this chapter or non-payment of fines assessed
under this chapter;
   (D)   The permittee has acted fraudulently in his, her or its dealings with
other persons, partnerships, corporations or the City; or
   (E)   The permittee has failed or refused in any material manner to comply
with this or any other ordinance or statute governing or regulating the
business of secondhand dealers or pawnbrokers.
§ 4-1-3-10. PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this
chapter shall be subject to the following fines:
      (1)   First offense - $50;
      (2)   Second offense - $100;
      (3)   Third offense - $200; and
      (4)   Any subsequent offense - up to $2,500.
   (B)   Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate
offense.
   (C)   In addition to the fines stated above, violation of any provision of
this chapter shall be grounds for suspension, revocation or denial of a permit.
(Am. Ord. 28, 2012, passed 12-19-2012)
CHAPTER 4. AUCTIONS AND SPECIAL SALES
Section
   
4-1-4-1.   Definitions
   
4-1-4-2.   Permit required
   
4-1-4-3.   Permit application
   
4-1-4-4.   Permit fees; duration
   
4-1-4-5.   Display of permit and record of sales required
   
4-1-4-6.   Permits non-transferable; valid only for original inventory
   
4-1-4-7.   Duties of permittees; generally
   
4-1-4-8.   Surrender of certain other business permits
   
4-1-4-9.   Person who has held sale within one year from date of application
not to be granted permit
   
4-1-4-10.   Revocation of permit; grounds
   
4-1-4-11.   Certain persons exempt from chapter
§ 4-1-4-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   AUCTION. A sale transaction conducted by means of oral or written
exchanges between an auctioneer and the members of his or her audience, which
exchanges consist of a series of invitations for offers for the purchase of
goods or real estate made by the auctioneer and acceptance of the highest or
most favorable offer made by a member of the participating audience.
   (B)   FIRE AND OTHER ALTERED GOODS SALE. A sale held out in a manner so as
to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods
damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means.
   (C)   GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALE. A sale held out in a manner so as to
reasonably cause the public to believe that, upon the disposal of the stock of
goods on hand, the business affairs of the person, firm or corporation will
cease and be discontinued.
   (D)   GOODS. Any goods, wares, chattels, merchandise or other personal
property, including domestic animals and farm products.
   (E)   SPECIAL SALE. The sale of or an offer to sell to the public goods of
any kind in connection with a declared purpose on the part of the seller that
the sale is anticipatory to the termination, closing, liquidation, revision,
wind-up, discontinuance, conclusion or abandonment of the business in
connection with the sale. It shall also include, but is not limited to, any
sale advertised to be a creditor’s sale, executor’s sale, administrator’s sale,
salvage sale, assignee’s sale, receiver’s sale, loss-of-lease sale, fire sale,
moving sale, relocation sale, going-out-of-business sale and all other sales
advertised in a manner so as to reasonably convey to the public that the person
conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale
upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and then will move to and resume
business at a new location or then will continue business from other existing
locations.
§ 4-1-4-2. PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to conduct or allow
to be conducted within the City of Lawrence any auction or special sale of
goods, except sales taking place under the direction of a court of competent
jurisdiction, without first having obtained a permit and having complied with
the provisions of this chapter.
Penalty, see § 1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-4-3. PERMIT APPLICATION.
   A person desiring to conduct an auction or special sale regulated by this
chapter shall make a written application to the City Controller setting forth
and containing the following information:
   (A)   The names and addresses of the owners of the goods to be offered for
sale or the names and addresses of the persons from whom the seller purchased
or obtained the goods to be offered for sale;
   (B)   A description, including the address, of the place where the sale is
to be held;
   (C)   The nature of the occupancy, whether by ownership, lease or sublease,
and the effective date of termination of the occupancy;
   (D)   The dates and the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted;
and
   (E)   The reason for the disposal of goods and the manner in which the sale
will be conducted; and a complete and detailed inventory of the goods to be
offered at the sale. The inventory shall be attached to and become part of the
application.
§ 4-1-4-4. PERMIT FEES; DURATION.
   (A)   Reserved.
   (B)   A permit issued under this chapter shall be valid for a period of 30
consecutive days from the issuance thereof or until the auction or special sale
is completed, whichever is shorter.
   (C)   The permit may be renewed for an additional period of time, not
exceeding 30 days, upon application being made for the renewal, accompanied by:
      (1)   A revised inventory showing items remaining unsold from the
original inventory.
(Am. Ord. 8, 2023, passed 11-6-2023)
§ 4-1-4-5. DISPLAY OF PERMIT AND RECORD OF SALES REQUIRED.
   (A)   Each person, firm or corporation conducting an auction or special sale
shall display his or her permit in a prominent place upon the premises where
the auction or special sale is conducted.
   (B)   The person, firm or corporation shall maintain accurate and complete
records of the disposition of each article, including the name and address of
the purchaser, the sale price and a description of articles sold. The records
shall be available to the police for inspection.
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-4-6. PERMITS NON-TRANSFERABLE; VALID ONLY FOR ORIGINAL INVENTORY.
   (A)   Permits provided for by this chapter may not be assigned or
transferred.
   (B)   Permits provided for by this chapter shall authorize only the sale of
the goods described in the original inventory attached to the original permit
application therefor, and no additional goods may be sold, whether under an
original or a renewal permit.
§ 4-1-4-7. DUTIES OF PERMITTEES; GENERALLY.
   In addition to the duties prescribed by §
4-1-1-4, every permittee under this chapter shall:
   (A)   Make no additions whatsoever during the period of the permitted sale
to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application
for permit; and
   (B)   Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading
advertising.
Penalty, see § 1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-4-8. SURRENDER OF CERTAIN OTHER BUSINESS PERMITS.
   Upon being issued a permit under this chapter for a going-out-of-business
sale or other liquidation type sale, the permittee shall surrender to the City
Controller all other business permits he or she may hold at that time
applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a permit
under this chapter.
Penalty, see § 1-1-2-3
§ 4-1-4-9. PERSON WHO HAS HELD SALE WITHIN ONE YEAR FROM DATE OF APPLICATION
NOT TO BE GRANTED PERMIT.
   Any person, firm or corporation who has held a going-out-of-business sale or
other liquidation style special sale as regulated under this chapter at the
location stated in the application within one year from the date of the
application shall not be granted a permit under this chapter.
§ 4-1-4-10. REVOCATION OF PERMIT; GROUNDS.
   In addition to the grounds prescribed by §
4-1-1-5, a permit or renewal thereof, issued pursuant to this chapter, may be
revoked by the Mayor after notice and hearing pursuant to I.C. 36-4-5-5 for any
of the following reasons:
   (A)   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application;
   (B)   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made as to the
inventory, stock sold or stock on hand; or
   (C)   Conducting the business permitted under this chapter in an unlawful
manner or in a manner so as to constitute a breach of the peace or to
constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public.
§ 4-1-4-11. CERTAIN PERSONS EXEMPT FROM CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following
persons:
   (A)   Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent
jurisdiction;
   (B)   Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public
officials; or
   (C)   Any person holding a moving sale, garage sale or other similar sale on
the premises of the person’s residence, provided that these sales do not occur
more frequently than two times in any one-year period.
ARTICLE 2. SPECIFIC BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1. SOCIAL CLUBS AND SKATING RINKS
Section
   
4-2-1-1.   Definitions
   
4-2-1-2.   Permits required; annual and individual
   
4-2-1-3.   Applications
   
4-2-1-4.   Reserved
   
4-2-1-5.   Denial of permit; grounds
   
4-2-1-6.   Dancing and skating events open to authorities
§ 4-2-1-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   SKATING RINK. Any business or place of business where the public
generally, or groups of persons, are invited to engage in skating for valuable
consideration, paid either directly or indirectly or as an incident to the
purchase of merchandise, food or beverage.
   (B)   SOCIAL CLUB. Any structure or place where the public generally, or
groups of persons, are invited to engage in dancing for valuable consideration,
paid either directly or indirectly or as an incident to the purchase of
merchandise, food or beverage.
§ 4-2-1-2. PERMITS REQUIRED; ANNUAL AND INDIVIDUAL.
   (A)   Except as allowed in division (D) below, it shall be unlawful for any
person, firm or corporation to operate or maintain a dance hall or skating rink
within the City without first obtaining a permit therefor from the City
Controller.
   (B)   Permits may be issued on an annual basis, per location, or on an
individual basis for each dancing or skating event.
   (C)   Individual permits issued pursuant to this chapter shall allow the
permittee to hold one dancing or skating event for a continuous period not to
exceed eight hours.
   (D)   Annual permits are valid for one location only.
   (E)   The permits otherwise required by this chapter shall not be required
under the following circumstances:
      (1)   For a dance or skating event held by a fraternal, educational,
governmental, political, charitable or religious organization, as long as
admission to the dance is limited to members and invited guests and as long as
the organization is not formed specifically for the purpose of holding dances
or skating events; or
      (2)   For any school or class, the purpose of which is to teach dancing
or skating.
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-2-1-3. APPLICATIONS.
   In addition to other information required of all permit applicants under
this code, applicants for permits under this chapter shall provide the
following information on the application form:
   (A)   Names and addresses of the owners, lessees and principal operators of
the business;
   (B)   Names and addresses of the owners of the real estate upon or within
which the business is conducted;
   (C)   The size, in square feet, of the premises within which dancing or
skating will take place; and
   (D)   The zoning classification of the property. Proper zoning must be
obtained prior to making application for a permit.
§ 4-2-1-4. RESERVED.
§ 4-2-1-5. DENIAL OF PERMIT; GROUNDS.
   In addition to the qualifications set out in §
4-1-1-3, the City Controller may refuse to issue a permit required by this
chapter for any of the following reasons:
   (A)   The application was not made at least 48 hours prior to the time of
commencement of the dancing or skating event;
   (B)   The applicant has been convicted of a violation of law relating to
intoxicating liquors, narcotics or disorderly or immoral conduct; or
   (C)   The applicant permitted violations of law to occur at a prior dancing
or skating event held by him or her, without stopping the violations or
reporting them to the police.
§ 4-2-1-6. DANCING AND SKATING EVENTS OPEN TO AUTHORITIES.
   Dancing and skating events operated under permits issued pursuant to this
chapter, as well as dancing or skating schools, shall at all times be open to
public authorities of the City for entrance, inspection and enforcement of this
code and state law, including regulations set by local fire authorities such as
occupancy and other public safety requirements.
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
CHAPTER 2. CONCERT HALLS AND THEATERS
Section
   
4-2-2-1.   Definitions
   
4-2-2-2.   Permits required; annual and individual
   
4-2-2-3.   Applications
   
4-2-2-4.   Reserved
   
4-2-2-5.   Concert halls and theaters open to authorities
§ 4-2-2-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   CONCERT HALL. Any structure or place where the public generally, or
groups of persons, are invited for the purpose of listening to and viewing live
musical presentations of individuals or groups of musicians for valuable
consideration, paid either directly or indirectly or as an incident to the
purchase of merchandise, food or beverage.
   (B)   THEATER. Any structure or place where the public generally, or groups
of persons, are invited for the purpose of listening to and viewing live
theatrical productions or individual performances or motion pictures,
television or other entertainment shown on a screen for valuable consideration,
paid either directly or indirectly or as an incident to the purchase of
merchandise, food or beverage.
§ 4-2-2-2. PERMITS REQUIRED; ANNUAL AND INDIVIDUAL.
   (A)   Except as allowed in division (D) below, it shall be unlawful for any
person, firm or corporation to operate or maintain a concert hall or theater,
indoor or outdoor, within the City without first obtaining a permit therefor
from the City Controller.
   (B)   Permits may be issued on an annual basis, per location, or on an
individual basis for each musical or theatrical presentation.
   (C)   Individual permits issued pursuant to this chapter shall allow the
permittee to hold one musical or theatrical presentation for a continuous
period not to exceed eight hours.
   (D)   The permits otherwise required by this chapter shall not be required
under the following circumstances:
      (1)   For a musical or theatrical event held by a fraternal, educational,
governmental, political, charitable or religious organization as long as the
organization is not formed specifically for the purpose of holding the musical
or theatrical events; or
      (2)   For any school or class, the purpose of which is to teach musical
or theatrical skills or to provide or complement a part of the regular
curriculum or approved extracurricular program.
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-2-2-3. APPLICATIONS.
   In addition to other information required of all permit applicants,
applicants for permits under this chapter shall provide the following
information on the application form:
   (A)   Names and addresses of the owners, lessees and principal operators of
the business;
   (B)   Names and addresses of the owners of the real estate upon or within
which the business is conducted;
   (C)   The size, in square feet, of the premises upon or within which the
licensed activities will take place; and
   (D)   The zoning classification of the property. Proper zoning must be
obtained prior to making application for a permit.
§ 4-2-2-4. RESERVED.
§ 4-2-2-5. CONCERT HALLS AND THEATERS OPEN TO AUTHORITIES.
   Concert halls and theaters operated under permits issued pursuant to this
chapter shall be open at all times to public authorities of the City for
entrance, inspection and enforcement of this code and state law.
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
CHAPTER 3. TAXICABS
Section
   
4-2-3-1.   Definitions
   
4-2-3-2.   License to operate taxicab required
   
4-2-3-3.   Applications for taxicab business license
   
4-2-3-4.   Initial application; approval by Common Council
   
4-2-3-5.   Renewal applications
   
4-2-3-6.   Insurance required; minimum limits
   
4-2-3-7.   License fees; transfer
   
4-2-3-8.   Vehicles eligible for license
   
4-2-3-9.   Taximeters
   
4-2-3-10.   Taxicab maintenance and inspection
   
4-2-3-11.   Names and numbers on taxicabs
   
4-2-3-12.   Advertising on taxicabs
   
4-2-3-13.   Articles found in taxicabs
   
4-2-3-14.   Unlawful acts pertaining to unlicensed taxicabs
   
4-2-3-15.   Taxicab driver’s license required
   
4-2-3-16.   Persons eligible for driver’s license
   
4-2-3-17.   Driver’s license applications
   
4-2-3-18.   Driver’s license application investigation
   
4-2-3-19.   Driver’s license issuance
   
4-2-3-20.   Reserved

4-2-3-22.   Driver’s license renewal procedure

4-2-3-24.   Employment of taxicab drivers
   
4-2-3-25.   Taxicab rates
§ 4-2-3-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   OWNER. Any person, firm or corporation holding any legal or beneficial
interest in a taxicab business or any of its assets or who is otherwise
entitled to any portion of the income from the business.
   (B)   SHAREHOLDER. Any person holding legal or beneficial title to any of
the corporate stock of any taxicab business.
   (C)   TAXICAB. Any motor vehicle operated for hire or to serve the public
and designed or constructed to accommodate and transport passengers, not more
than six in number including the driver, and which does not operate on a fixed
schedule or over any definite and designated routes within the City, the
destination of which is designated by the passenger or passengers at the time
of the transportation; provided that ambulances and funeral cars are not
included in this definition.
   (D)   TAXICAB BUSINESS. Any business, the purpose of which is to dispatch or
otherwise operate one or more taxicabs within the City.
§ 4-2-3-2. LICENSE TO OPERATE TAXICAB REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab or maintain a
business, the purpose of which is to operate taxicabs, within the City without
first obtaining and keeping in effect at all times a license therefor from the
City Controller.
Penalty, see § 1-1-2-3
§ 4-2-3-3. APPLICATIONS FOR TAXICAB BUSINESS LICENSE.
   (A)   All applications for a license required by this chapter shall be made
and signed by the owner or owners of the business.
   (B)   In addition to the information required of all license applicants
under this code, the following information shall be provided by all applicants
under this chapter:
      (1)   Name, address and phone number, date of birth and social security
number of the owner or owners of the taxicab business;
      (2)   If applicant is a corporation, the names, addresses and telephone
numbers of all members of the corporate board of directors and shareholders;
      (3)   Criminal convictions of any owner, or if a corporation, of any
member of the corporate board of directors or shareholders;
      (4)   License history of applicant(s), including previous suspensions and
revocations of any similar license issued in this or any other state;
      (5)   The address and telephone number of the place(s) of business within
the City from which the taxicab service will be operated, including dispatch
office, central business office and maintenance and repair facilities;
      (6)   The name(s) and address(es) of the owner(s) and lessor(s) of the
real estate upon or within which the taxicab business will be operated;
      (7)   The total number of taxicabs intended to be used in the business;
      (8)   On separate sheets for each taxicab, the year, make, model, serial
number, engine number, license plate number, passenger and weight capacity and
statement of mechanical condition of each taxicab intended to be used in the
business, along with a picture of each taxicab;
      (9)   A listing of the names, addresses, telephone numbers, social
security numbers and dates of birth of all employees, agents or partners who
will operate the taxicab(s) for the applicant, along with the registered
numbers and dates of expiration for each individual operator’s Indiana Public
Passenger Chauffeur’s license issued pursuant to the requirements of I.C. 9-24-
5;
      (10)   A complete financial statement of the owner(s), firm or
corporation desiring to operate the taxicab service.
§ 4-2-3-4. INITIAL APPLICATION; APPROVAL BY COMMON COUNCIL.
   (A)   All initial applications for licenses to operate a taxicab business
shall be filed with the Board of Public Works and Safety. The Board shall
conduct an investigation into the personal, business and criminal histories of
all persons and corporations listed on the applications.
   (B)   At the conclusion of the investigation, the Board shall set a date for
a public hearing to consider the need for the taxicab service.
   (C)   At the conclusion of the hearing, the Board shall reduce its
recommendation to writing, and the City Controller shall present the
recommendation, along with the application, to the Common Council at its next
regular meeting.
   (D)   The Common Council shall consider the matter and may either deny the
license, stating its reasons therefor, or may order the City Controller to
issue the license for the business described in the application, and shall
prescribe the number of taxicab licenses which the applicant shall be
authorized to be issued by the City Controller.
§ 4-2-3-5. RENEWAL APPLICATIONS.
   (A)   Renewal license applications may be processed by the City Controller
without action by the Board of Public Works and Safety or the Common Council so
long as the taxicab business license has not been suspended or revoked or the
number of taxicab licenses desired does not exceed the number previously
authorized by the Common Council.
   (B)   Where the license has been suspended or revoked within the previous
year, or where the licensee desires to increase the number of taxicabs beyond
the number authorized by the Common Council, the application shall be treated
as a new application with the requisite hearing and associated cost of an
initial license.
§ 4-2-3-6. INSURANCE REQUIRED; MINIMUM LIMITS.
   (A)   Prior to the issuance of a license for any taxicab or taxicab
business, the applicant for the license shall provide the City Controller with
a certificate of liability insurance covering each taxicab to be licensed.
   (B)   The insurance policy shall be issued by a company authorized to do
business in the State of Indiana and shall be in at least the amount of
$100,000 combined coverage for bodily injury and property damage for each
taxicab operated in the business.
   (C)   The liability insurance certificate shall require the insuring company
to provide the City of Lawrence with at least 30 days’ prior written notice of
cancellation.
   (D)   Failure to maintain proper insurance on each taxicab in the minimum
amounts stated shall be grounds for revocation of the business license.
§ 4-2-3-7. LICENSE FEES; TRANSFER.
   (A)   The taxicab business license shall be posted in a conspicuous place
within the licensed premises. In addition, each taxicab shall be issued a
separate taxicab license which shall be posted in a conspicuous place within
the taxicab and visible to the occupants.
   (B)   Taxicab business licenses are non-transferable.
   (C)   Individual taxicab licenses may be transferred by the owner to another
taxicab owned by the same business, but only if the taxicab originally licensed
is permanently retired from service.
   (D)   Taxicab transfer licenses may be obtained by turning in the old
taxicab license and paying a $5 transfer fee to the City Controller.
   (E)   Transferred licenses shall bear the same expiration date as that of
the original license.
   (F)   All license fees shall be paid prior to the licenses being issued and
are non-refundable.
(Am. Amended Ord. 8, 2023, passed 11-6-2023) Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-2-3-8. VEHICLES ELIGIBLE FOR LICENSE.
   (A)   All vehicles used as taxicabs shall be a type of motor vehicle having
four doors, a rigid roof, a rear trunk and seats, which are designed to seat
four passengers plus the driver comfortably.
   (B)   No taxicab license shall be issued, pursuant to this chapter, for any
vehicle which, at the time the license is issued, is more than ten years older
than the current model year of passenger automobiles.
(Am. Ord. 30, 2010, passed 1-3-2011) Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-2-3-9. TAXIMETERS.
   (A)   Every taxicab operated within the City shall be equipped with a
taximeter or standard fare register device approved by the Board of Public
Works and Safety, which device shall be designed to correctly measure and
indicate the time in operation, the distance traveled and the fare to be
charged. The meters shall be inspected by a police officer as hereinafter
provided.
   (B)   Meters found to be operating properly and accurately when inspected
shall be sealed by the inspecting police officer. Any meter found to be
functioning improperly shall either be repaired or replaced with a properly
functioning meter and reinspected before the taxicab is placed back into
operation.
   (C)   All taximeters required by this chapter shall be illuminated between
sunset and sunrise so as to be easily and clearly readable at all times by
passengers.
   (D)   All taximeters required herein shall be in an enclosed case, and it
shall be unlawful for any person other than the inspecting police officer to
remove or tamper with the seal placed on any meter in accordance with the
provisions of this section or to tamper with the meter or case, unless he or
she is repairing it, and the meter shall be reinspected after repair.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab for hire
while the meter is not in operation or at a rate of fare other than prescribed
by this chapter. It also shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab
so as to indicate that it is occupied by a passenger for hire when it is not.
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-2-3-10. TAXICAB MAINTENANCE AND INSPECTION.
   (A)   All taxicabs licensed pursuant to this chapter shall be carefully
maintained on a regular basis so as to keep the vehicles well painted,
reasonably free of dirt and free of mechanical defects at all times.
   (B)   No license to operate a taxicab shall be issued by the City Controller
until there is filed, along with the permit application for the vehicle, a
certificate, executed by the inspecting police officer of the Lawrence Police
Department, showing that the officer has inspected the vehicle’s tires, brakes,
steering apparatus, alignment, lights, windshield wipers, bumpers, metering
device and general mechanical condition and has found the vehicle to be in such
a condition that it may be safely operated in the City and that the metering
device operates properly and measures accurately.
   (C)   In addition to the initial inspection, every taxicab licensed pursuant
to this chapter shall be inspected, as prescribed by division (B) above, at
least three times annually in April, July and October of each year.
   (D)   Upon successful completion of each inspection, the inspecting police
officer shall issue a certificate of compliance, attesting that the vehicle is
in compliance with the provisions and requirements of this chapter.
   (E)   Failure of any taxicab to successfully pass inspection in any
enumerated area shall require the taxicab to be withdrawn from service until
the time that corrective action is taken sufficient to bring the vehicle into
compliance with the requirements of this chapter and the vehicle has been
reinspected and issued a certificate of compliance by the inspecting officer.
   (F)   Failure of any taxicab to successfully pass inspection on three or
more occasions shall be grounds for revocation of the taxicab’s license.
Repeated failure of taxicabs to pass inspection shall also be grounds for
revocation of the taxicab business license.
   (G)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to ensure that all
vehicles operated by the licensee, and licensed pursuant to this chapter, are
inspected as prescribed by this section and that the certificates of compliance
are delivered to the City Controller in a timely fashion. Failure to have
vehicles inspected as prescribed or failure to deliver certificates of
compliance to the City Controller within ten days of inspection shall be
grounds for revocation of the taxicab license.
Penalty, see §
1-1-2-3
§ 4-2-3-11. NAMES AND NUMBERS ON TAXICABS.
   (A)   Every taxicab licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall have
