approval of the transfer. The application shall provide complete information
regarding the proposed transfer, including:
      (1)   Documents embodying the transaction;
      (2)   Financing documents, if any;
      (3)   Documents describing the proposed transferee;
      (4)   Documents identifying any person or entity who will be responsible,
through any arrangement, for managing or controlling the system;
      (5)   Documents showing that the proposed transferee has the financial,
technical and legal ability to operate the system after the transfer so as to
satisfy all its obligations under the franchise without adversely affecting
subscribers; and
      (6)   Other information as may be required in any ordinance governing
applications for a franchise.
   (C)   The City of Lawrence shall render a final decision on the operator’s
request in writing within 120 days of the date the City receives the
information specified above and information required by federal law. The City
of Lawrence may seek additional information from the operator or the proposed
transferee and both will cooperate to provide the information to the City. The
City of Lawrence shall be under no obligation to transfer the franchise if the
operator’s acts or omissions make the franchise subject to revocation, nor
shall the City be required to transfer unless it is fully satisfied that past
nonperformance will be corrected, claims that could be considered as part of
any renewal proceeding are fully preserved to the extent permitted by law, and
the proposed transferee has the ability and is likely to comply with the
franchise agreement for the future. By way of illustration and not limitation,
under no circumstances will the franchise be transferred unless the proposed
transferee agrees to accept all the terms and conditions of the franchise
agreement except to the extent that the City of Lawrence may be willing to
expressly modify the terms and conditions as part of the approval of the
transfer. Approval of transfer does not constitute a waiver of any rights by
the City of Lawrence or indicate that the operator is or has been in compliance
with the franchise agreement or applicable law. The City of Lawrence may
conduct the public hearings as it deems appropriate to consider the transfer
request.
   (D)   The operator, upon transfer, shall within 60 days file with the City
of Lawrence a copy of the deed, agreement, mortgage, lease or other written
instrument evidencing transfer of ownership control or lease of the system,
certified and sworn to as correct by the operator.
   (E)   A transfer shall include any sale of system assets, a transfer of the
franchise itself or a change in control or ownership of the operator. The term
“control” includes actual working control in whatever manner exercised, and
there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a transfer shall have occurred
upon acquisition or accumulation by any person or entity of 5% of the shares or
interest in the operator or any entity which owns or controls the operator.
CHAPTER 8. HOTELS, MOTELS AND PLACES OF PUBLIC LODGING
Section
   
4-2-8-1.   Definitions
   
4-2-8-2.   Inspections
   
4-2-8-3.   License required; renewal
   
4-2-8-4.   Duty to keep register
   
4-2-8-5.   General qualifications of licensees
   
4-2-8-6.   Licensees must not be indebted to City, county or state
   
4-2-8-7.   Standards and requirements of license
   
4-2-8-8.   Licensing powers and duties of the City Controller
   
4-2-8-9.   Application contents generally
   
4-2-8-10.   License insignia and certificates
   
4-2-8-11.   Inspections of licensed hotels
   
4-2-8-12.   Right of entry for inspections and enforcement
   
4-2-8-13.   Penalties and violations
   
4-2-8-14.   Enforcement of orders affecting licensees; license revocation and
suspension
   
4-2-8-15.   Appeal and review
§ 4-2-8-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   APPLICANT. The person or entity who makes application for a license
and who will be the licensee if the license is granted.
   (B)   APPLICATION. The written form provided by the City Controller upon
which an applicant may apply for a license.
   (C)   FINANCIAL INTEREST.
      (1)   (a)   Any of the legal rights of ownership or beneficial interest
in the profits of a business;
         (b)   Any portion of the legal rights of ownership in any partnership,
corporation or other legal entity having any portion of the rights or
beneficial interest; or
         (c)   Equal to or greater than 5% of the whole.
      (2)   FINANCIAL INTEREST includes, but is not limited to, that interest
held by stockholders and officers of corporations or similar business entities.
   (D)   HOTEL. All places and rooms where the general public is furnished
lodging, either regularly or occasionally, for private profit.
   (E)   LICENSE. The privilege of carrying on the business of a hotel within
the City.
   (F)   PREMISES. All real estate (including structures and fixtures affixed
thereto) used in the business of the hotel together with all equipment,
vehicles, furnishings and other personal property used in connection therewith.
   (G)   PUBLIC WELFARE. The health, safety, prosperity and convenience of the
inhabitants of the City, either as a whole or individually.
§ 4-2-8-2. INSPECTIONS.
   All hotels shall be subject, on demand, to health, building, fire safety,
zoning and all other lawful inspections by all governmental agencies having
jurisdiction over the hotel and its location.
§ 4-2-8-3. LICENSE REQUIRED; RENEWAL.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and operate a hotel in
the City without first procuring a license therefor from the City Controller.
There shall be no fee for this license. No person shall operate or permit the
operation of a hotel when the license thereof has been suspended, revoked or
expired.
   (B)   Each license issued pursuant to this section shall be issued for
annual periods and shall be renewed automatically by the City Controller and
without application for renewal by the licensee, unless the license at the time
of renewal has been revoked or suspended, or is the subject of administrative
or judicial proceedings which have the potential to result in the revocation or
suspension of the license as provided in this chapter. All annual licenses
issued by the City Controller for an existing or new hotel shall expire on
January 1 of the following calendar year. All renewals shall be dated on or as
of January 1 of the year of issuance.
Penalty, see § 4-2-8-13
§ 4-2-8-4. DUTY TO KEEP REGISTER.
   Any person owning, operating or managing any hotel shall keep a permanent
record of each guest receiving lodging and the date or dates thereof, which
record shall be made available upon demand for inspection by any police
officer.
Penalty, see § 4-2-8-13
§ 4-2-8-5. GENERAL QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEES.
   In order to obtain a license as required by this chapter, the applicant
shall meet the following requirements.
   (A)   The applicant and all persons having a financial interest in the
applicant or the associated premises must not have had a license to operate a
hotel revoked or suspended because of the conduct and operation of the hotel or
because of the violation of any law or regulation while maintaining and
conducting that hotel within the 12 months preceding the date of the
application.
   (B)   The applicant must agree to comply with all laws, provisions of this
code and other ordinances, all regulations created hereunder and the orders and
decisions of all public officials which pertain to the hotel and premises, and
shall also agree that the hotel and premises will not be used for any unlawful
purposes.
   (C)   If not a natural person, the applicant shall be organized and
controlled by the laws of the State of Indiana or be authorized and qualified
to engage in business in the State of Indiana.
§ 4-2-8-6. LICENSEES MUST NOT BE INDEBTED TO CITY, COUNTY OR STATE.
   No license shall be issued, renewed or transferred if the licensee or
prospective licensee is delinquent to the City, county or state for any taxes,
or is indebted to the City, county or state for any reason unless the
indebtedness or delinquency is the subject of pending litigation as provided by
ordinance or statute. All applicants shall state under oath that they are not
in violation of the provisions of this section, and if any violation of this
section is found, it shall be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of
the license.
§ 4-2-8-7. STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or
other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act
of the licensee; and the licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if
the act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally.
   (B)   Every licensee shall:
      (1)   Permit inspections of the hotel and its premises by public
authorities acting pursuant to law;
      (2)   Conduct, maintain and supervise the hotel and its premises in a
manner so as not to create a nuisance or be or become inimical to the public
welfare;
      (3)   Keep the hotel and its premises clean and free from any sort of
rubbish or combustible or explosive material;
      (4)   Not permit any sort of illegal activity, conduct or practices to
take place within the hotel or on its premises or in the conduct and provision
of its business and services; and
      (5)   Provide the City Controller with written notice of any additions or
changes in the information given in the license application within 30 days of
the additions or changes.
   (C)   All license applications and license renewals shall be approved by the
Department of Metropolitan Development for zoning compliance, by the Department
of Public Works for building code compliance and by the Fire Department for
fire safety compliance.
   (D)   All licenses shall be issued upon the condition that the licensee
comply with all laws and ordinances, all regulations promulgated hereunder and
the orders and decisions of all public officials which pertain to the hotel and
premises. All licenses shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the City
Controller for any violation of law by the licensee.
Penalty, see § 4-2-8-13
§ 4-2-8-8. LICENSING POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE CITY CONTROLLER.
   (A)   The City Controller shall issue all hotel licenses in the name of the
City.
   (B)   In deciding whether or not to issue, revoke or suspend a license, the
City Controller may request or receive recommendations from any source to act
upon in the City Controller’s discretion.
   (C)   The City Controller is hereby given the following general powers with
respect to licensing hotels:
      (1)   To adopt all forms to be used in applications and licenses;
      (2)   To adopt, issue, amend, rescind and enforce reasonable regulations
and orders in the administration and enforcement of all provisions of this
chapter;
      (3)   To institute an investigation to determine the qualifications of
the applicant or licensee. Each applicant for a license or the renewal of a
license shall have the burden of proving that the applicant is qualified and is
entitled to a hearing before the City Controller or someone appointed by the
City Controller to present evidence as to the applicant’s qualifications. Each
applicant for a license may be required by the City Controller to submit
evidence under oath or in the form of an affidavit. No charge shall be made by
any notary public employed by the City for any affidavit required under this
section;
      (4)   To request or receive information from any source regarding an
applicant or licensee, either during the course of a hearing or otherwise;
      (5)   To exercise sound discretion, taking into consideration the effect
of the hotel or proposed hotel on the public welfare, including in particular
its effect on surrounding property and nearby residents and businesses;
      (6)   If the City Controller finds an applicant qualified to receive the
license for which the applicant has applied, the City Controller shall issue
the license with the official seal of the City affixed;
      (7)   If any license is refused by the City Controller, the reasons for
the refusal shall be stated in writing and delivered to the applicant upon
request; and, if the applicant remedies the reasons for the refusal and becomes
qualified for the license, and the facts are presented the City Controller and
found by the City Controller to be correct, the license then shall be issued;
and
      (8)   In the granting or denying of any license, the City Controller may
take into consideration the effect of the hotel upon surrounding property and
upon residents or inhabitants thereof; and in granting, denying or revoking the
license, the City Controller may exercise sound discretion as to whether the
license should be granted, transferred, denied or revoked.
§ 4-2-8-9. APPLICATION CONTENTS GENERALLY.
   (A)   All applications for licenses shall include, but not be limited to,
the following: the name and business address of the applicant, the names and
addresses of all persons who have a financial interest in the business, the
name in which the business will be conducted and the address of the hotel to be
licensed.
   (B)   All applications shall be signed personally by the applicant, and if
the applicant is not a natural person, then by an authorized representative of
the applicant.
§ 4-2-8-10. LICENSE INSIGNIA AND CERTIFICATES.
   (A)   The City Controller shall prescribe and provide a form for the license
to be obtained and displayed by licensees pursuant to this chapter. The City
Controller may change the design or form of the insignia or license from time
to time.
   (B)   All hotels shall post and maintain the license at a conspicuous place
in the licensed hotel where the license can be seen easily at all times.
   (C)   No person shall alter, forge or in any way modify or deface a license
issued by the City Controller under this chapter.
Penalty, see § 4-2-8-13
§ 4-2-8-11. INSPECTIONS OF LICENSED HOTELS.
   (A)   The City Controller may have hotels licensed under this chapter
inspected by employees of the City Controller or employees of other departments
of the City government or other appropriate units of government to determine if
the licensee is violating any requirements imposed by law upon the hotel. All
boards and officials of the City shall issue the necessary orders to their
respective employees to conduct the inspections requested by the City
Controller pursuant to this section.
   (B)   All violations of law observed during any inspection of a licensed
hotel or observed by police, fire, health, building, zoning or other officials
in the performance of their duties immediately shall be reported to the City
Controller and the Corporation Counsel.
§ 4-2-8-12. RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTIONS AND ENFORCEMENT.
   All employees of the City who have been authorized by the City Controller to
make inspections may enter any place of business of a licensee under this
chapter to make inspections conducted in a reasonable manner and at reasonable
times. The City Controller may call upon City employees having police power to
enforce the provisions of this chapter and the orders and decisions of the City
Controller and the Board of Public Works and Safety.
§ 4-2-8-13. PENALTIES AND VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Any person violating the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise
specified, shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in the general penalty
section of this code, §
1-1-2-3.
   (B)   Violations of this chapter or licensing regulations duly promulgated
by the City Controller pursuant to authority granted in this chapter shall
constitute a municipal ordinance violation. Any person violating this chapter
or the licensing regulations shall be subject to penalties prescribed for
violation of a municipal ordinance as prescribed in the general penalty section
of this code, §
1-1-2-3.
§ 4-2-8-14. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS AFFECTING LICENSEES; LICENSE REVOCATION AND
SUSPENSION.
   (A)   Upon learning of a violation of law by a licensee, the City Controller
shall issue a provisional order to the licensee setting forth the violation.
The provisional order shall be delivered to the licensee and shall inform the
licensee of all the licensee’s rights under this chapter.
   (B)   If any licensee, by the conduct and operation of the hotel and
premises, creates a situation or nuisance inimical to the public welfare, or is
charged in any court with an offense involving fitness to hold a license, and
the City Controller determines that an emergency exists, the license of the
licensee may be temporarily suspended by the City Controller without a hearing.
The order temporarily suspending the license shall be delivered to the licensee
and shall inform the licensee of all of the licensee’s rights under this
chapter.
   (C)   The City Controller shall cause personal service of all notices and
orders to be made on the person concerned, either by personal delivery or by
certified mail, with return receipt requested. In the absence or disability of
a licensee, a copy of the notice shall be affixed to some structure on the
premises where it may be readily found or observed by the licensee, or it may
be delivered to any agent or employee of the licensee upon the premises, and
the licensee shall be bound thereby. Depositing the notice in the United States
mail shall constitute service thereof.
   (D)   Each licensee who is subject to a provisional order or temporary
suspension under division (B) above shall have ten days in which to remedy the
reasons causing the provisional order or temporary suspension to be issued. Ten
days after notice has been given of a temporary suspension or provisional
order, another inspection shall be conducted and the results reported to the
City Controller, who shall either reinstate the license in the case of a
temporary suspension, rescind or modify the provisional order or revoke the
license.
   (E)   Upon written application of the licensee during the ten-day period, or
upon the City Controller’s own motion, a hearing shall be conducted by the City
Controller during which evidence shall be presented under oath by both the
licensee and those inspectors or others knowing the reasons why the license
should be revoked. Upon the completion of the hearing the City Controller shall
reinstate the license, rescind or modify the provisional order or temporary
suspension or revoke the license.
   (F)   At any time during the ten-day period, the licensee may request in
writing a reasonable extension of the time to remedy the reasons for which the
provisional order or temporary suspension was issued. The City Controller may
grant or deny the request in the discretion of the City Controller or the City
Controller may order a continuance or extension of time on the City
Controller’s own motion.
   (G)   In all cases where the license is revoked or suspended, the decision
of the City Controller shall be reported in writing to the licensee affected
and a certified copy of the decision shall be filed in the City Controller’s
office within 24 hours from the time of the decision. The decision shall become
effective upon issuance by the City Controller.
   (H)   Once a license has been revoked, it shall not be renewed or reissued,
and a new license shall not be issued for any hotel to be conducted by or for
the same licensee on any premises within six months after the revocation if the
same licensee is shown to have any financial interest therein or to have any
direct or indirect control of the hotel.
   (I)   If after a hearing a license is revoked or suspended and not
reinstated on appeal, the licensee shall pay to the City the cost of hearings
in connection with the revocation or suspension. The City Controller shall
determine the costs incurred by the City for the hearings, including, but not
limited to: court reporter’s fees, the costs of transcripts or reports,
attorney’s fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all
other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the City, or a lesser sum as the City
Controller may allow. The costs shall be paid to the City within 30 days of
notification of the costs by the City Controller.
§ 4-2-8-15. APPEAL AND REVIEW.
   (A)   The City Board of Public Works and Safety shall serve as the appeal
and review board for licenses pursuant to this chapter.
   (B)   Whenever a licensee or applicant for a license wishes to appeal any
decision of the City Controller refusing to issue or renew a license or
suspending or revoking a license, the licensee or applicant shall first appeal
to the Board. In order to appeal to the Board, the licensee or applicant shall
send a written notice of appeal to the City Controller, by certified mail with
return receipt requested, or by personal service with a signed receipt. The
notice to the City Controller must be received by the City Controller within 20
days of the date of issuance of the decision from which the appeal is being
made.
   (C)   Upon receipt of the notice of appeal served pursuant to division (A)
above, the City Controller shall notify the Board. The Board thereupon shall
set a hearing and shall notify the licensee or applicant and the City
Controller of the hearing date, time and place at least five working days prior
to the hearing.
   (D)   All hearings shall be conducted by the Board or Administrative Law
Judge in the manner prescribed by the Administrative Adjudication Act (I.C. 4-
21.5-3-1 through 4-21.5-3-37), and the determination of the Board or
Administrative Law Judge shall be subject to judicial review as provided in
that Act.
   (E)   The applicant or licensee shall bear the burden of proof that the City
Controller decision should be vacated because it was either unlawful, based
upon an incorrect factual record or otherwise an abuse of the City Controller’s
discretion. The City Controller or a person appointed by the City Controller
may present evidence at the hearing, which supports the City Controller’s
decision causing the appeal to be taken.
   (F)   The decision of the Board or Administrative Law Judge on an appeal
under this section shall be final, and the decision, together with the reasons
therefor, shall be delivered in writing within 30 working days from the close
of the hearing to the person taking the appeal, and a certified copy shall be
delivered to the City Controller, who shall keep all decisions on file in the
City Controller’s office. All decisions shall become effective upon delivery to
the City Controller.
CHAPTER 9. CHILD CARE FACILITIES
Section
   
4-2-9-1.   Definitions
   
4-2-9-2.   Requirement of registration
   
4-2-9-3.   Fee for registration
   
4-2-9-4.   Availability of information
   
4-2-9-5.   Enforcement
§ 4-2-9-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   CHILD. A person under 13 years of age.
   (B)   CHILD CARE FACILITY. A residence, commercial, religious, special use
or any other building and premises provided or maintained by a person or
persons to whom the child or children are unrelated by blood or marriage and
where one or more children are cared for, educated or otherwise present in
consideration of and exchange for the payment of a fee or fees in any amount;
provided, however, that a residence which provides only care for a child or
children in foster care or for a child or children cared for in random
babysitting without a fixed schedule or regularity of such care shall not be
deemed to be a CHILD CARE FACILITY. The term CHILD CARE FACILITY shall include,
but not be limited to, a “child care center”, a “child care home”, a “child
care ministry”, a “class I child care home” and a “class II child care home” as
defined by I.C. 12-7-2-28.4, 28.8, 33.7 and 33.8, respectively.
(Ord. 6, 2006, passed 7-3-2006; Am. Ord. 7, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-9-2. REQUIREMENT OF REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Any child care facility located in the City of Lawrence, whether
licensed by any unit of government or unlicensed, and after the effective date
of this chapter or, if such facility is established after the effective date of
this chapter, within 15 days after its opening, shall register with the City
Controller as hereinafter provided. The registration shall include the
following information:
      (1)   The address of the residence, building or facility;
      (2)   The portion or portions of the building and premises, if less than
all, where the child care is provided;
      (3)   The days and maximum specifically designated hours when the child
care is provided;
      (4)   The maximum number of children for whom the child care is provided;
      (5)   The ages of the child or children for whom care or services are
provided;
      (6)   Whether or not special needs children are cared for by the child
care facility;
      (7)   The name of the entity and the name or names and addresses of the
owner or owners and principal or principals who provide, maintain and operate
the child care facility and the services which it provides;
      (8)   Whether or not one or more animals are kept on the property and, if
so, the species, breeds and number;
      (9)   Whether or not a swimming pool, in ground or above ground, is
located on the property; and
      (10)   Such other data and information as reasonably may be requested by
the City Controller.
   (B)   The City Controller shall prepare and provide to registrants a form or
forms on which the operator or operators of child care facilities shall provide
the information requested by this chapter. The required registration shall be
verified by the operator or operators and shall be renewed and resubmitted
annually by each operator or operators. A copy of the completed registration
form for each year shall be provided to the person or persons completing such
form. The child care facility, upon completion of the registration form, shall
be provided a certificate by the City Controller, which certificate shall be
conspicuously posted and displayed in the child care facility at all times.
   (C)   The Public Safety Communications Department shall be responsible for
entering the information acquired from the registration process into the
records and electronic data system of the city so that it is available as
provided in §
4-2-9-4.
(Ord. 6, 2006, passed 7-3-2006; Am. Ord. 7, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-9-3. FEE FOR REGISTRATION.
   Each child care facility registered pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter shall pay an annual registration fee of $20 to the City of Lawrence to
defray the cost of the registration process and its implementation and
enforcement.
(Ord. 6, 2006, passed 7-3-2006; Am. Ord. 7, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-9-4. AVAILABILITY OF INFORMATION.  
   The information requested by and provided pursuant to this chapter shall be
available to and accessible by all public safety personnel responding to any
emergency call from or pertaining to the child care facility and shall be
available at all times to the City of Lawrence Fire Department, Police
Department, Public Safety Communications Department and Department of Public
Works.
(Ord. 6, 2006, passed 7-3-2006; Am. Ord. 7, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-9-5. ENFORCEMENT.
   Failure by any person or persons to comply with the provisions of this
chapter may result in a penalty of $20, in addition to the payment of the fee
required by §
4-2-9-3 in order to comply with this chapter. Any second or other subsequent or
continuing failure by any person or persons to comply with the provisions of
this chapter may result in a penalty of $100 for each such second or other
subsequent or continuing failure to comply.
(Ord. 7, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
CHAPTER 10. AUTOMOTIVE SALES AND RELATED ACTIVITIES
Section
   
4-2-10-1.   Location of automotive sales
   
4-2-10-2.   Free movement into and from automotive sales locations
   
4-2-10-3.   Placement of vehicles
   
4-2-10-4.   Structures
   
4-2-10-5.   Maintenance, repair and storage on automotive sales locations
   
4-2-10-6.   Refuse and debris
   
4-2-10-7.   Interference with movement and unobstructed view
§ 4-2-10-1. LOCATION OF AUTOMOTIVE SALES.
   Any and all automotive-related uses, including but not limited to new and/or
used motor vehicle sales, shall be conducted on and at sites and locations
which are properly zoned, granted an appropriate variance of use and/or
development standards or qualified by valid pre-existing nonconforming use. Any
and all such automotive related uses which are closed or terminated because of
cessation of business, abandonment, damage to or destruction of any improvement
or improvements on the property, sale of the property or business or for any
other reason whatsoever for a period of 60 or more days may not be re-
established or re-opened unless all standards and requirements of the
applicable zoning ordinance or ordinances and the requirements of this and all
other applicable provisions of law are satisfied. In addition, all automotive
related sales shall be conducted only on and at sites and locations where the
primary use is automotive sales. Automotive sales, whether continuing or random
and from time to time, may not be conducted on they premises of other retail
establishments, including, but not limited to, grocery stores and food markets,
or at residence locations unless it is a vehicle registered to a licensed
driver residing at the residential address.
(Ord. 13, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-10-2. FREE MOVEMENT INTO AND FROM AUTOMOTIVE SALES LOCATIONS.
   Automotive sales lots and locations must be so designed, planned,
established, conducted and used that motor vehicles displayed, stored, in
transit or belonging to members of the public while parked do not for any time
occupy or block entrances, exits, curb cuts, easements, sidewalks or any
portion or portions of the property provided for ingress, egress and the
movement of vehicles into, from or on the property.
(Ord. 13, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-10-3. PLACEMENT OF VEHICLES.
   Automotive sales lots and locations must provide a minimum space measuring
not less than nine feet in width and not less than 18 feet in length but, in no
instance, less than 180 square feet in total area for the outdoor display and
placement of each motor vehicle offered for sale, for the parking of each motor
vehicle by personnel of the facility and by members of the public and for any
other motor vehicle otherwise present or located on the property. No motor
vehicle offered or to be offered for sale or awaiting service or repair shall
be parked or placed on any public street, road or right-of-way.
(Ord. 13, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-10-4. STRUCTURES.
   The management, conduct and operation of any and all automotive sales lots
and locations shall be only from one or more affixed and permanent structures
located on the premises. Any and all such structures at all times shall comply
with all applicable building, fire, health, zoning and other applicable
statutes, ordinances, codes, regulations and standards.
(Ord. 13, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-10-5. MAINTENANCE, REPAIR AND STORAGE ON AUTOMOTIVE SALES LOCATIONS.
   Any and all maintenance or repair of motor vehicles on any automotive sales
lot or inside any structure located on such premises shall be performed only if
it is performed entirely within an enclosed structure and in such a manner that
it also complies with, meets and satisfies any and all applicable building,
fire, health, zoning and other applicable statutes, ordinances, codes,
regulations and standards. Any and all inoperable motor vehicles and motor
vehicles awaiting service or repair or otherwise in storage or unavailable for
immediate sale as an operable and merchantable motor vehicle shall be parked or
placed in an area which is separate and distinct from the area or areas where
operable and merchantable motor vehicles available for immediate sale and other
operable vehicles in active and current use are parked or placed; provided,
however, that no inoperable motor vehicle, no motor vehicle awaiting service or
repair and no motor vehicle otherwise in storage or unavailable for immediate
sale as an operable and merchantable motor vehicle shall be parked, placed or
otherwise present anywhere on the property for in excess of 30 days.
(Ord. 13, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-10-6. REFUSE AND DEBRIS.
   Owners and operators of any and all automotive sales lots and locations
shall keep and maintain their property at all times in a neat, orderly and
clean condition free of litter, debris, automotive parts and equipment and any
and all other refuse or items awaiting use, transportation or disposal. Any and
all refuse, trash and discarded items or material awaiting disposal, recycling,
remanufacturing or transportation must be placed entirely inside a dumpster or
other container or containers which at all times are enclosed within a solid,
complete, fully opaque and closed area.
(Ord. 13, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
§ 4-2-10-7. INTERFERENCE WITH MOVEMENT AND UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW.
    No placement of any motor vehicle or vehicles, sign or signs or other
temporary or permanent location of any item or object related or pertaining in
any way to any automotive sales lot or location shall be, either entirely or in
part, in or on any public right-of-way or on any adjoining property.
Advertising, signs, banners, pennants, flags, balloons and any and all physical
objects used in any manner to attract attention to or promote any automotive
sales lot or location and the motor vehicles located there may not in any
manner block, limit or impair in any way the unobstructed view and the free and
unlimited movement and passage of the vehicular, pedestrian or other traffic on
any public way, including a sidewalk or sidewalks.
(Ord. 13, 2009, passed 4-6-2009)
CHAPTER 11. SPECIAL EVENTS CODE
Section
   
4-2-11-1.   Title
   
4-2-11-2.   Purpose and intent
   
4-2-11-3.   Definitions

4-2-11-1. TITLE.
   These provisions shall be known as the Special Events Code of the City of
Lawrence and shall be cited as such and will be referred to herein as “this
code.”
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-2. PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   (A)   It is the purpose of the Common Council (the “Common Council”) of the
City of Lawrence (the “City”) to establish a comprehensive framework for the
issuance of special events permits, facilitating a wide array of public
activities including, but not limited to, vehicle/boat shows, auctions,
concerts/live music, festivals/carnivals, mass participation sports,
exhibitions, outdoor markets, community gatherings, games of chance such as
bingo, lotteries, food and beverage sales, displays involving fireworks, lasers
or pyrotechnics, and closures of public rights-of-way. Recognizing the vital
role these events play in enhancing the cultural, social and economic fabric of
our community, the City is committed to promoting a vibrant communal life.
These events not only enrich the lifestyle of the City’s residents by offering
diverse experiences and fostering community engagement but also attract
visitors, showcasing what the City has to offer.
   (B)   Furthermore, acknowledging the invaluable contributions of tax-exempt,
non-profit organizations to the welfare and quality of life in the City, this
code aims to support these entities in their efforts to organize events that
generate the necessary resources to deliver essential services to the City’s
residents. By delineating special event venues, this code seeks to complement
existing land use regulations, ensuring a well-coordinated approach to managing
the various activities associated with special events. This includes
safeguardingthe health and safety of event attendees, prohibiting unlawful
activities within event venues and upholding the rights and privileges of
special event permit holders.
Additionally, this code is designed to institute a fair and efficient mechanism
for the recovery of costs and sharing of revenues derived from certain special
events. In doing so, it aims to minimize any potential negative financial
impacts on events that play a pivotal role in enriching the community’s
cultural and social landscape. Through the thoughtful regulation and support of
special events, the City endeavors to foster a dynamic, inclusive and thriving
community for all its residents and visitors.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-3. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (A)   APPLICANT. Any individual or entity applying for a permit under this
code to organize and conduct a special event. For events on public property,
the APPLICANT shall be the individual or entity responsible for the event’s
operation. For events on private property, the property owner shall be deemed
the APPLICANT.
   (B)   ATTENDANCE. The anticipated number of individuals expected to attend
or participate in a special event, whichever figure is higher.
   (C)   BLOCK PARTY. A distinct event held by and for the residents of a
specific neighborhood or group of neighborhoods for a period of one day or
less.
   (D)   CITY PROPERTY. All real property and structures owned, operated, or
controlled by the City within its jurisdiction, including but not limited to
public buildings, parks, streets, sidewalks and recreational facilities.
   (E)   COMMERCIAL SPECIAL EVENT. Any special event organized and conducted by
any person, party or entity that does not qualify as a tax-exempt non-profit
organization.
   (F)   DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS. The designated authority responsible for
the approval and issuance of special event permits within the City.
   (G)   EVENT OPERATOR/ORGANIZER. The individual, organization or entity
responsible for managing, staging, promoting or sponsoring a special event.
   (H)   EVENT SPONSOR. The person, party or entity that sponsors a special
event and has applied for a special event permit under this chapter.
   (I)   NON-COMMERCIAL SPECIAL EVENT. Any special event organized and
conducted by any person, party or entity that qualifies as a tax-exempt non-
profit organization.
   (J)   OUTDOOR. Any location or area not contained within a permanent
building, encompassing temporary structures, tents, canopies and open-air
spaces.
   (K)   REVIEWING AUTHORITY. The Department of Public Works is designated to
review, approve, and issue special event permit applications within the City.
   (L)   SPECIAL EVENT. For the purposes of the City, a special event
encompasses a wide range of organized gatherings, assemblies, activities or any
combination thereof, which may require the use of or impact public property,
facilities, emergency services or City services.
   (M)   SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT. An official authorization issued by the
Department of Public Works allowing the holder to conduct a special event in
accordance with the provisions of this code.
   (N)   SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT ADMINISTRATOR. For the purposes of this code and
related administrative processes, the term SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT ADMINISTRATOR
is defined as the Director of the Department of Public Works or their designee.
   (O)   SPECIAL EVENT VENDOR. Any individual, organization, or entity
providing goods or services within the confines of a special event venue during
the duration of an approved event.
   (P)   SPECIAL EVENT VENUE. The designated area for which a special event
permit has been granted, encompassing the location(s) where the event
activities will take place.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-4. SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT REQUIRED.
   This section underscores the importance of obtaining a special event permit
prior to organizing an event in the City, it outlines the authority of the
Special Event Permit Administrator in managing the permitting process, setting
event boundaries and coordinating with other agencies, all aimed at ensuring
events are conducted safely and with minimal disruption to the City’s daily
operations.
   (A)   Permit requirement. No person, organization or entity shall conduct,
promote, manage, aid or solicit attendance at a special event within the City
without first obtaining a special event permit pursuant to this chapter. This
requirement is designed to ensure the safety, health and well-being of
participants, residents and the general public, as well as to minimize
disruptions to the community and local businesses.
   (B)   Special events requiring a permit.
      (1)   (a)   Events regardless of number of attendees:
            1.   Auctions, in conjunction with § 4-1-4 of the Lawrence
Municipal Code;
            2.   Food and/or beverage sales; and
            3.   Vehicle/boat shows.
         (b)   Events where expected attendance or participants exceed 100
people:
            1.   Concerts/live music, not including reoccurring performances at
bars or restaurants;
            2.   Festivals/carnivals;
            3.   Bingo, drawings, lotteries or similar games; and
            4.   Weddings, on residential properties.
         (c)   Street gatherings with unusual traffic arrangements. Any
formation, procession, or assemblage of people, animals, vehicles, or a
combination thereof, taking place on a public street and not adhering to the
usual or standard traffic regulations or controls. This aims to ensure the
safety and smooth flow of traffic and pedestrians. This includes:
            1.   The sale or distribution of food or beverages on streets,
sidewalks, or other public places or public property, or on private property
where otherwise prohibited by ordinance;
            2.   Erection or placement of:
               A.   Tent, utility pole or other temporary structure;
               B.   A stage, bandshell, trailer, van, portable building,
grandstand, bleachers or other apparatus used for entertainment purposes; and/
or
               C.   Temporary signage, banners or displays of any kind; on a
street, sidewalk, alley or other public place, in or over a public right of
way, or on private property where otherwise prohibited by ordinance.
         (d)   Public venue assemblies. Organized groups of individuals
gathering at a public venue for a shared purpose, managed under the guidance of
a responsible person or entity. These events are designed to foster community
engagement, entertainment or informational sharing in a structured environment.
         (e)   Activities affecting public property or City services. This
category includes a diverse array of events such as:
            1.   Closure of public right-of-way;
            2.   Mass participation sports (e.g., marathons, bicycle races);
            3.   Spectator sports;
            4.   Exhibitions;
            5.   Outdoor markets;
            6.   Community events;
            7.   Fireworks, lasers, and/or pyrotechnics; and
            8.   Parades.
         (f)   The Special Event Permit Administrator has discretion to
determine whether a particular gathering of individuals is a special event.
Such factors to be used in their determination shall include (but not be
limited to) the number of attendees, impact on city resources and duration of
the gathering/event.
      (2)   Each of the above-mentioned events, by their nature, may introduce
unique requirements or considerations regarding the use of public spaces,
traffic management, public safety and community impact. The inclusion of such a
comprehensive list within the definition aims to ensure that all potential
special events falling under these categories are adequately planned, permitted
and managed to minimize disruptions and maximize benefits to the City and its
residents.
   (C)   Permit authority and responsibilities. The Special Event Permit
Administrator, is vested with the authority to:
      (1)   Issue permits. Grant special event permits for activities occurring
within the City limits in accordance with the procedures outlined in this
chapter. This includes assessing each application to ensure that the proposed
event complies with all relevant regulations and standards.
      (2)   Venue boundaries. Establish reasonable boundaries for the special
event venue. This determination shall balance the needs and requirements of the
event with the public health, safety and welfare of the City. The designated
boundaries will help to manage the impact on local traffic, businesses and
residents. Parades shall be scheduled to move from its point of origin to its
point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays enroute.
      (3)   Interagency coordination. Collaborate with other public agencies
whose jurisdictions or properties may be impacted by the event. The Department
of Public Works shall coordinate the issuance of a special event permit with
these agencies, ensuring that all necessary approvals are obtained. A permit
will be issued upon the concurrence of all involved agencies, ensuring a
unified approach to managing the event’s impact on the community and public
resources.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-5. AUTHORIZED SPECIAL EVENT VENDORS.
   (A)   The issuance of a special event permit confers upon the permit holder
or event sponsor the right to control and regulate the sale of goods, food, or
beverages within the special event venue in accordance with the terms and
conditions of the special event permit.
   (B)   Issuance of a special event permit shall license all special event
vendors listed in the approved application for the date of the event for the
purposes of conducting business activities in the City.
   (C)   Special event vendors must possess appropriate local, state, or
federal permits and/or licenses to conduct business in the City for inclusion
in the event.
   (D)   Vendors authorized to sell goods, food, or beverages in the special
event venue shall display their authorization in the manner required by the
Special Event Permit Administrator. Only vendors displaying the required
authorization shall be allowed to sell goods, food, or beverage in the special
event venue.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-6. ISSUANCE OF A SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT DOES NOT OBLIGATE CITY SERVICES.
   This section establishes the framework within which the City manages its
involvement in special events, clarifying that the issuance of a permit does
not guarantee City support services. It also outlines the process through which
services can be provided, ensuring that such decisions are made transparently
and with due consideration for the City’s interests.
   (A)   No obligation for services. The issuance of a special event permit by
the City, in accordance with this chapter, does not create an obligation or
requirement for the Department of Public Works or any other City department to
provide city services, equipment, or personnel in support of a special event.
The granting of a permit is primarily for authorization and coordination
purposes and does not automatically entail support services from the City.
   (B)   Provision of services. Subject to the approval of the Common Council,
the Department of Public Works may provide City services, equipment, or
personnel to support special events. Such support is discretionary and must be
considered on a case-by-case basis, weighing the benefits to the community
against the cost and logistical implications for the City. Approval from the
Common Council is not mandated for the Department of Public Works to offer City
services, equipment, or personnel for a special event, provided that
arrangements have been made with the event organizer for cost recovery or
revenue sharing, or both. This ensures that while the City can support special
events that contribute positively to the community, it does so in a manner that
is financially responsible and sustainable.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-7. PRIORITY OF SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   Scheduling priority for special event permits within the City shall be
determined according to the following order of precedence, with Group 1 being
afforded the highest priority and Group 3 the lowest. Permit issuance will be
conducted on a first-come, first-served basis within each group. Upon approval
by the Department of Public Works, changes to the approved event date may be
considered.
   (A)   Eligible user groups.
      (1)   Group 1: Civic-Sponsored Events. These events are directly
sponsored by the City and/or involve significant partnership with civic
organizations that have a long-standing tradition of serving the City’s
community.
      (2)   Group 2: Non-Commercial Special Events. These include events
organized by non-profit organizations or community groups that do not have a
primary commercial purpose and are aimed at providing services, entertainment,
or benefits to the citizens of the City without a significant commercial
objective.
      (3)   Group 3: Commercial Special Events. These events are primarily
commercial in nature, organized by businesses or commercial entities with the
intent of profit-making. While these events can also offer cultural,
recreational, or community benefits, their primary aim is commercial success.
   (B)   In cases where multiple applications are received for the same event
date, priority shall be given to organizations operating within and providing
services to the citizens of the City whenever feasible. This prioritization
scheme is to ensure that events with the greatest potential benefit to the
community are given precedence in the allocation of special event permits.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-8. TIME FOR FILING APPLICATION FOR SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   All special event permit applications must be submitted in writing using the
designated special event permit application form provided by the Special Event
Permit Administrator. Applications must be filed no less than 45 days and no
more than one year before the proposed event date. Applications received less
than 45 days before the event's scheduled date will incur a late fee.
Furthermore, these late applications will be processed on a secondary basis and
will not receive priority over applications that have been submitted in
accordance with the specified 45-day timeframe. This policy encourages timely
submissions to allow for the thorough evaluation and coordination necessary to
ensure the event can be accommodated without compromising public safety, city
services, or the quality of the event experience.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-9. APPLICATION FOR SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   This section ensures that all aspects of the special event are considered
and planned for in advance, promoting a safe and successful event within the
City. Applicants are encouraged to provide detailed and accurate information to
facilitate the review and approval process. The following outlines the
comprehensive information and documentation required to apply for a special
event permit:
   (A)   Required information. An application for a special event permit must
include detailed information about the event to assist in its evaluation and
planning:
      (1)   Proposed date(s) of the special event;
      (2)   Geographic location of the event area, including specific
boundaries;
      (3)   Estimated attendance, encompassing vendors, attendees, and
participants;
      (4)   Street closures, specifying locations and duration;
      (5)   Alcohol provision/consumption areas, if applicable;
      (6)   Temporary structures, such as tents, canopies, and stages, with
detailed descriptions;
      (7)   Advertising materials, including signs, banners, and their
specifications;
      (8)   Entertainment details, including types and duration;
      (9)   Sanitation plan, outlining waste management and facilities like
toilets and wash stations;
      (10)   Emergency safety plan, detailing security measures, fire
protection, medical services, and the responsible event safety officer;
      (11)   Traffic management plan, including personnel, loading areas,
barricades, parking, etc.;
      (12)   Neighboring property coordination, affirming communication with
adjacent property owners;
      (13)   Additional information as requested by the Special Event Permit
Administrator.
   (B)   Required attachments.
      (1)   Site plan or route map, indicating the event layout with clear
identification of streets and key locations;
      (2)   Permit documentation, proving the filing of local, state, or
federal permits relevant to the event;
      (3)   Certificate of insurance naming the City as an additional insured,
which amounts of insurance may vary according to the specific type of activity
occurring;
      (4)   Identification, a valid driver’s license or state-issued ID of the
event sponsor; and
      (5)   Additional documentation as requested by the Special Event Permit
Administrator.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-10. FEE FOR SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   (A)   For the City, the following fee structure has been established for the
application and issuance of special event permits to ensure that the costs
associated with the administrative processes, planning, and potential City
services are adequately covered:
      (1)   Base permit fee. A non-refundable base fee of $150 is required for
all special event permit applications submitted 45 days or more prior to the
event date. This fee is applicable to all events regardless of their nature or
size.
      (2)   Late application fee. For applications received less than 45 days
prior to the event, an additional fee of $300 per day will be assessed, in
addition to the $150 base application fee, to accommodate the expedited
processing required.
      (3)   Vendor fees.
 
Fee Amount Number of Vendors
$100       For events with 1 to 10 vendors
$200       For events with 11 to 25 vendors
$300       For events with 26 or more vendors
 
These fees are in addition to the base permit fee and are intended to cover the
additional administrative costs of managing vendor participation
      (4)   Waiver for civic sponsored events. The permit fee may be waived, by
the Special Event Permit Administrator or their designee, for events sponsored
by civic organizations, recognizing their contribution to the community’s
welfare and engagement.
      (5)   Fee adjustments and waivers. The Special Event Permit Administrator
reserves the right to adjust or waive application fees for non-commercial
special events or commercial special events based on the event's nature, scope
and anticipated community benefit.
      (6)   Non-refundable fee. Except as explicitly stated, all application
fees are non-refundable to ensure that the City can recover the administrative
costs incurred during the application review process.
   (B)   Special considerations for fee adjustments or waivers aim to encourage
a wide range of events beneficial to the community, balancing administrative
needs with community engagement and support.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-11. WHEN APPLICATION FOR SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT IS DEEMED COMPLETE.
   An application for a special event permit within the City is considered
complete when the applicant has satisfactorily fulfilled all requirements set
forth in the application process. This includes the submission of comprehensive
details as outlined in the application form, alongside any supplementary
information or documentation deemed necessary by the Special Event Permit
Administrator for a thorough evaluation of the proposed event. Additionally,
the application is only recognized as complete upon the full payment of the
applicable permit fee, as specified in the City’s fee structure for special
event permits.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-12. CONDITIONS AFFECTING THE ISSUANCE OF A SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   (A)   The issuance of a special event permit by the City’s Special Event
Permit Administrator is contingent upon the fulfillment of specific conditions
aimed at ensuring public safety, minimizing disruptions to daily life, and
maintaining the quality of life within the community. A special event permit
may be issued when all the following conditions are satisfactorily met:
      (1)   Minimal disruption to traffic and public transport. The event must
be planned in such a manner that it does not significantly interrupt the flow
of public transportation, vehicular, and pedestrian traffic within and around
the event area.
      (2)   No conflict with public works. The event should not interfere with
ongoing construction, development activities in the public right-of-way or
operations at public facilities.
      (3)   Avoidance of peak traffic hours. The scheduling of the event must
avoid blocking traffic lanes or street closures during the peak commute hours
on weekdays, to minimize impact on the City’s traffic flow.
      (4)   Limited impact on police and fire resources. The event should not
necessitate the diversion of a large number of police or fire personnel from
their normal duties, ensuring that the City can continue to provide reasonable
protection and services to all areas.
      (5)   Emergency vehicle access. There must be adequate planning to ensure
that the concentration of people, animals or vehicles does not impede the
movement of public safety and emergency vehicles.
      (6)   Efficient movement. The event must progress from its starting point
to its conclusion without unnecessary stops, ensuring it does not unduly
obstruct the area for an extended period.
      (7)   Consideration of community impact. The event should be planned with
an understanding of its potential effects on local residents, businesses, and
traffic patterns, taking steps to mitigate adverse impacts.
      (8)   Sporting event limitations. If the event involves a participatory
sport, it should not be scheduled within 30 days of another similar sporting
event in the area, to avoid overburdening local resources and infrastructure.
      (9)   Adequate health facilities. The event provides sufficient means of
sanitation and utilizes the appropriate recycling or waste collection services
to be available in or adjacent to any public assembly areas, as necessary.
   (B)   To ensure compliance with these conditions, the Special Event Permit
Administrator reserves the right to impose specific stipulations on the permit.
Additionally, if the event necessitates significant alterations to vehicular
traffic patterns, including the closure of streets or public rights-of-way,
final approval from the Common Council will be required.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-13. REASONS FOR DENIAL OF A SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   (A)   The City's Special Event Permit Administrator is vested with the
authority to assess and either approve or deny applications for special event
permits. A special event permit may be denied under the following
circumstances:
      (1)   Incomplete application. If an applicant has not fulfilled all the
necessary requirements for submitting a complete application for a special
event permit.
      (2)   Public safety concerns. If the proposed event is deemed likely to
incite violent or disorderly conduct, posing an imminent threat to public
safety or likely to result in significant property damage.
      (3)   Violation of laws. If the event is found to potentially violate
existing public health or safety laws.
      (4)   Non-compliance with legal or policy requirements. If the event does
not adhere to applicable laws or established council policies.
      (5)   Past non-compliance. If the applicant has previously demonstrated
an inability or unwillingness to conduct an event in accordance with the
chapter’s terms and conditions, or if a past event authorized to the applicant
did not comply with legal or permit requirements.
      (6)   Unreasonable use or access restriction. If the event would
necessitate the exclusive use of a public area in a way that adversely affects
the general public’s reasonable use or access to that area.
      (7)   Lack of necessary approvals or permits. If the applicant has not
obtained required approvals or permits from other relevant public agencies
whose jurisdictions would be affected by the event.
      (8)   Inadequate emergency plans. If the applicant has failed to provide
a satisfactory first aid or emergency medical services plan, taking into
account the risk factors associated with the event.
      (9)   Late application. Applications submitted less than 45 days prior to
the event date are subject to denial.
      (10)   Non-compliance with chapter terms or previous permit conditions.
If the applicant has not adhered to any chapter term or condition stipulated in
a previously issued special event permit.
      (11)   Substantial adverse impacts. The proposed special event will
substantially interfere with any other event, parade, City sponsored event,
street or right-of-way closure or other special event for which a license has
already been granted, or substantially interfere with the provision of public
safety or other City services in support of such other previously scheduled
event or events, or will have an immitigable adverse impact upon residential or
business access and traffic circulation in the area in which it is to be
conducted.
   (B)   These criteria ensure that events conducted within the City limits are
safe, lawful, and in harmony with the community's standards and regulations.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-14. APPEAL FROM DENIAL OF A SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   (A)   Notification of denial. If a special event permit is denied, the
applicant will be notified in writing by the Special Event Permit Administrator
as soon as reasonably possible.
   (B)   Appeal process. The denial of a special event permit can be appealed
to the Common Council.
   (C)   Filing an appeal. An appeal must be made in writing within five
business days of receiving the written denial, by submitting a written petition
to the City Clerk outlining the grounds for the appeal.
   (D)   Hearing. The Common Council will hear the appeal within 30 days of
receiving it.
   (E)   Final decision. The Common Council’s decision on the appeal, whether
approval or denial, is the final administrative remedy available to the
applicant.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-15. DISPLAY OF SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A copy of the special event permit must be prominently displayed at the
special event venue in accordance with the guidelines set by the Special Event
Permit Administrator. This permit should be readily available for presentation
upon request by any City official. Additionally, the permit copy sign shall
measure at least 24 by 36 inches, be made of all-weather-proof material and
must be posted at the special event venue in a conspicuous location.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-16. CONTENTS OF SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   The special event permit may include, but is not limited to, the following
information or conditions:
   (A)   Location and map of the venue.
   (B)   Dates, assembly areas, and times.
   (C)   Specific route plan.
   (D)   Minimum and maximum speeds.
   (E)   Number and types of participants, animals, vehicles, and any sound-
producing equipment, with noise limitations.
   (F)   Maximum space interval between booths or structures.
   (G)   Occupied portions of street or sidewalk and location of stands.
   (H)   Number and location of traffic controllers and support personnel.
   (I)   Area and time for disbanding.
   (J)   Conditions for alcohol use and vendor control by the event sponsor.
   (K)   Required emergency medical services.
   (L)   Other necessary information and conditions for event conduct and
chapter enforcement.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-17. SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT ADMINISTRATOR'S ACTION ON APPLICATION.
   (A)   Final action timing. The Special Event Permit Administrator will act
on a completed application as soon as practicable, not required before 45 days
prior to the event.
   (B)   Incomplete applications. No action is required on incomplete.
   (C)   Application processing limit. No more than one application per
applicant will be processed in any two-week period.
   (D)   Final action options. The application can be approved, approved with
modifications, or denied.
   (E)   Informed decision. The Special Event Permit Administrator shall
communicate the special event permit decision to the applicant in writing.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-18. INSURANCE REQUIRED TO CONDUCT SPECIAL EVENT.
   (A)   Liability insurance. Special event sponsors must secure comprehensive
general liability insurance to indemnify the City against liability for damages
arising from the event. This insurance should name the City, its officials,
employees, agents, and any other pertinent public entities as additional
insured parties. The coverage must be maintained throughout the event duration,
with immediate notice of cancellation provided to the City. The minimum
coverage required is a combined single limit of $1,000,000.
   (B)   Insurance adjustments. The required coverage amount may be adjusted
based on the event’s risk category.
   (C)   Documentation. Insurance documentation must be filed with the Special
Event Permit Administrator 30 days prior to the event unless modified for good
cause.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-19. REVOCATION OF SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT.
   (A)   Grounds for revocation. Permits may be revoked if the event cannot be
conducted within permit standards, violates any condition of the permit, poses
a health or safety threat, lacks required permits or was issued in error.
   (B)   Revocation notice. Written notice specifying the reasons for
revocation will be provided, with verbal notice allowed in emergencies.
   (C)   Appeal process. Appeals from revocation are handled similarly to
permit denials.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-20. COST RECOVERY FOR SPECIAL EVENTS.
   (A)   In the pursuit of balancing community enrichment with fiscal
responsibility, the City mandates the recovery of costs directly associated
with the facilitation of special events.
      (1)   Recovery of direct costs. The City will, except in cases where
costs are funded or waived by Council action, require special event organizers
to compensate for expenses incurred by the City in support of the event. This
includes, but is not limited to:
         (a)   Costs related to ensuring public safety through traffic control,
fire safety services and the provision of other necessary support by City
facilities or personnel.
         (b)   The City of Lawrence reserves the right to impose additional
cost(s) related to public safety personnel for repeated emergency or non-
emergency calls that incur costs related to manpower, vehicle use and
administrative processing in accordance with any and all laws and regulations
and City ordinances.
         (c)   Expenses arising from the utilization of City equipment and
services, including the provision and management of waste disposal solutions
such as trash receptacles, and the subsequent removal and disposal of waste
generated during the event.
      (2)   Cost estimation and notification. The Special Event Permit
Administrator will, upon request, furnish an estimate of the anticipated costs
associated with the event. This estimation is provided in conjunction with the
review of the event application to facilitate the organizer’s planning and
budgeting process.
      (3)   Fee payment requirement. Organizers are obligated to pay the
assessed fees, or a reasonable approximation thereof, upon the approval of
their application. The City acknowledges that extenuating circumstances may
arise, and in such instances, the Special Event Permit Administrator may extend
the payment deadline as deemed appropriate.
      (4)   Penalties for non-compliance with cleanup and repair.
         (a)   Organizers failing to adequately clean up or repair damages to
the event venue or its vicinity will be invoiced for the actual costs incurred
by the City in rectifying these issues. An administrative fee, reflecting the
expenses of property inspection and compliance verification, will be
additionally imposed.
         (b)   Should an organizer previously have neglected their cleanup or
repair obligations under an issued permit, the City may require a deposit of
adequate surety, either in cash or bond form, as a precondition for future
permit approval.
   (B)   This cost recovery framework underscores the City’s commitment to
fostering community events while ensuring the stewardship of its resources and
the well-being of its citizens.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-21. SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT ADMINISTRATOR AUTHORIZED TO ADOPT RULES AND
REGULATIONS.
   Subject to approval by the Common Council, the Special Event Permit
Administrator is authorized to promulgate additional rules and regulations that
are consistent with and that further the terms and requirement set forth within
this chapter and the provisions of law that pertain to the conduct and
operation of a special event.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-22. OTHER PERMITS AND LICENSES.
   (A)   The issuance of a special event permit does not relieve any person
from the obligation to obtain any other permit or license pursuant to local,
state or federal code.
   (B)   The issuance of any other permit or license issued pursuant to local,
state or federal code does not relieve any person from the obligation to obtain
a special event permit pursuant to this chapter.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-23. UNLAWFUL TO USE CITY NAME WITHOUT AUTHORIZATION.
   It is unlawful for any special event sponsor to use in the title of any
event the words “City of Lawrence” or a facsimile of the City seal without the
City’s authorization.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-24. ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY.
   The Special Event Permit Administrator, or his or her designee, is
authorized to administer and enforce the provision of this chapter. Nothing in
this chapter shall limit applicable enforcement authority of any local, state
or federal authority on matters where said authorities are authorized to
exercise jurisdiction.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-25. UNLAWFUL TO INTERFERE WITH SPECIAL EVENT.
   It is unlawful for any person to obstruct, impede, or interfere with any
authorized assembly, person, vehicle or animal participating in an event for
which a special event permit has been issued.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-26. COST RECOVERY FOR UNLAWFUL SPECIAL EVENT.
   Whenever a commercial or non-commercial special event is conducted without a
special event permit when one is required, or an event is conducted in
violation of the terms of an issued special event permit, the special event
sponsor shall be responsible for, and the Special Event Permit Administrator
shall charge the special event sponsor for, all City costs incurred for
personnel and equipment for public safety response caused or necessitated by
the adverse impacts of the event, or the violation of the special event permit,
upon public safety plus an administrative fee of $500 for administrative tasks
to determine lack of compliance.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-27. PENALTY FOR VIOLATION.
   Any special permit holder violating this chapter may have its permit revoked
after hearing and shall be fined a sum not exceeding the amount of the special
permit fee required to be paid pursuant to this chapter. Any person who is not
a permit holder violating this chapter shall be fined the sum of twice the
applicable permit fee. Each day that the violation occurs or continues shall
constitute a separate offense. Any action brought to recover fines, fees or
costs imposed under this chapter may be collected by filing
suit in Marion Superior Court. In the event legal proceedings are necessary to
recover fines, fees or costs, or if legal action is instituted to enforce or
seek judicial review of this ordinance, the City shall be entitled
reimbursement of legal fees associated with enforcement, defense or judicial
review.
(Ord. 8, 2024, passed 7-17-2024)
§ 4-2-11-28. SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT FEES.
