Recreation,” with service of process being had upon the President of the Board,
but costs may not be taxed against the Board or its members in any action;
      (12)   Invoke any legal, equitable or special remedy for the enforcement
pursuant to I.C. 36-10-3-11;
      (13)   Release and transfer, by resolution, a part of the area over which
it has jurisdiction for park and recreational purposes to park authorities of
another unit for park and recreational purposes upon petition of the park or
recreation board of the acquiring unit; and
      (14)   Exercise any other power provided by law.
   (B)   The Board may also lease any buildings or grounds belonging to the
unit and located within a park to a person for a period not to exceed 50 years.
The lease may authorize the lessee to provide upon the premises educational,
research, veterinary or other proper facilities for the exhibition of wild or
domestic animals in wildlife parks, dining facilities, amusement rides
generally found in amusement parks or other recreational facilities. A lease
may be made for more than one year only to the highest and best bidder, after
notice that the lease will be made has been given by publication in accordance
with I.C. 5-3-1.
   (C)   Notwithstanding division (B) above, the Board may lease buildings or
grounds belonging to the unit for a period of more than one year without
soliciting the highest and best bidder or providing notice under I.C. 5-3-1 if:
      (1)   The buildings or grounds are leased to an Indiana nonprofit
corporation;
      (2)   The buildings or grounds are operated as a public golf course; and
      (3)   The golf course remains subject to rules and regulations
promulgated by the Board.
§ 6-1-1-8. BOARD DUTIES.
   The Board shall perform the following duties:
   (A)   Exercise supervision of and make rules for the Department;
   (B)   Establish rules and regulations governing the use of all parks and
recreation facilities by the public;
   (C)   See that police protection is provided for parks and recreation
property and activities;
   (D)   Appoint necessary administrative officers of the Department and fix
their duties;
   (E)   Establish standards and qualifications, without regard to political
affiliation, for all Department employees;
   (F)   Make an annual report to the Mayor and Common Council concerning the
operation of the Department and its programs;
   (G)   Prepare and submit an annual budget to the Common Council;
   (H)   Fix the compensation of Department officers and employees subject to
the provisions of I.C. 36-4-7; and
   (I)   Perform all other duties required by law.
§ 6-1-1-9. SUPERINTENDENT; APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS.
   (A)   The Superintendent shall be appointed by the Mayor pursuant to I.C.
36-4-9-2, subject to the approval of the Board of Parks and Recreation.
   (B)   The Superintendent must:
      (1)   Be qualified by training or experience in the field of parks and
recreation; or
      (2)   Have a certification or an advanced degree in the field of parks
and recreation.
§ 6-1-1-10. SUPERINTENDENT; DUTIES.
   Under the direction of the Board, the Superintendent shall:
   (A)   Propose annually a plan for the operation of the Department;
   (B)   Administer the plan as approved by the Board;
   (C)   Supervise the general administration of the Department;
   (D)   Keep the records of the Department;
   (E)   Recommend persons for appointment as assistants if the Board
determines the need;
   (F)   Appoint employees of the Department, subject to the approval of the
Board, according to the standards and qualifications fixed by the Board,
without regard to political affiliation;
   (G)   Prepare and present to the Board an annual report; and
   (H)   Perform other duties that the Board directs.
CHAPTER 2. PROGRAMMING POLICIES
Section
   
6-1-2-1.   Leisure programs policy
   
6-1-2-2.   Cooperative use of local resources
   
6-1-2-3.   Departmental planning
   
6-1-2-4.   Regulations governing use of park facilities
   
6-1-2-5.   Fees and charges
   
6-1-2-6.   Establishment of nonreverting operating fund
   
6-1-2-7.   Advisory Council and/or special committees
§ 6-1-2-1. LEISURE PROGRAMS POLICY.
   (A)   The Board shall attempt to provide the public with a wide and diverse
range of leisure services to meet the needs of all segments of the community.
   (B)   The Board shall encourage all members of the community to become
involved in the planning, implementation and evaluation of leisure services.
§ 6-1-2-2. COOPERATIVE USE OF LOCAL RESOURCES.
   (A)   Recreational programming shall be coordinated, where practicable, with
other community recreation sponsors and providers in order to minimize
unnecessary duplication of services and facilities.
   (B)   In addition, cooperative efforts with the Lawrence Township School
Corporation shall be particularly aimed at developing dual purpose facilities
throughout the City, suitable for both educational and recreational purposes.
   (C)   Involvement of citizens and local service organizations in the
implementation of the recreational programs shall be encouraged.
§ 6-1-2-3. DEPARTMENTAL PLANNING.
   (A)   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall develop a master plan
outlining projected development of recreational programming, services and
facilities.
   (B)   The plan shall include projections of both short and long range
anticipated needs for leisure services and facilities within the community.
   (C)   Input from the community shall be encouraged and solicited at all
stages in the development of the Department’s planning process.
§ 6-1-2-4. REGULATIONS GOVERNING USE OF PARK FACILITIES.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall establish rules and regulations
governing the use of park facilities by the public.
§ 6-1-2-5. FEES AND CHARGES.
   (A)   The Board shall, wherever possible, make parks and recreation services
available to the public free of charge.
   (B)   In cases where a fee must be charged in order to provide particular
services, the fee rate shall be established and approved by the Board of Parks
and Recreation.
§ 6-1-2-6. ESTABLISHMENT OF NONREVERTING OPERATING FUND.
   (A)   A special nonreverting operating fund is hereby established within the
Department of Parks and Recreation, pursuant to I.C. 36-10-3-22.
   (B)   Funds received by the Department of Parks and Recreation from the
operation of all programs and concession stands shall be deposited into the
special nonreverting operating fund.
   (C)   Expenditures from this fund may be made by the Board of Parks and
Recreation with appropriation, only on approved claims allowed by the Board of
Public Works and Safety.
   (D)   Umpires for softball leagues played through the City of Lawrence
Department of Parks and Recreation shall be paid on a contractual basis at a
rate in accordance with the Amateur Softball Association rules and regulations
as established annually.
(Am. Ord. 11, 2004, passed 8-2-2004)
§ 6-1-2-7. ADVISORY COUNCIL AND/OR SPECIAL COMMITTEES.
   (A)   The Board of Parks and Recreation may, from time to time, appoint an
Advisory Council or special committees to study problems or subjects specified
by the Board and then report back to the Board their recommendations.
   (B)   The Advisory Council and/or special committees shall be established in
accordance with the provisions of I.C. 36-10-3-17.
